review: Originally written as a lecture, it makes for a wonderful audiobook (read by Juliet Stevenson, a fantastic British actress you would recognize as one Originally written as a lecture, it makes for a wonderful audiobook (read by Juliet Stevenson, a fantastic British actress you would recognize as one who is always in the great British ensemble movies). It feels as timely and relevant today as when the lecture was given nearly 100 years ago. This is one of those books I should have had to read at some point in my education, but unless you were an English major few people did. Which is infuriating-- and gets right to the central thesis of her lecture. Woman have been overlooked for all of history, and without a decent income, independence, and a "room of one's own" in which to write, women will never be able to achieve all to which they are aspire or are capable of. So many excellent arguments made. Should be required reading for all. ...more

review: Listened to as an audiobook read by Saunders, and he is wonderful reader of his own stories. The first and last short stories (Victory Lap and 10th ofListened to as an audiobook read by Saunders, and he is wonderful reader of his own stories. The first and last short stories (Victory Lap and 10th of December) are magnificent. 10th of December may be the most honest, moving short story I have ever read. The stories in between the first and last feel perfectly placed in a Black Mirror world — a not too distant future, unsettling, and occasionally gut punching. A recurring theme of poverty or feeling “not enough” and the steps people will take in the hope of making life better for their loved ones. He’s the kind of writer that you read and desperately wish you had just 10% of Saunders’ talent. ...more

review: 3.5 stars. I wanted to read this book after seeing it on so many banned book lists. It's a YA "memoir manifesto" written for those who are young, blac3.5 stars. I wanted to read this book after seeing it on so many banned book lists. It's a YA "memoir manifesto" written for those who are young, black, and queer; I am none of those things, so I'm not sure it's my place to write a . I truly appreciate that it exists and I hope it does serve as a reflection and starting place for those who aren't seen nearly enough in memoirs or popular culture. That said, I had hoped for it to be more reflective and deeper in its storytelling. There were moments in some essays when it felt more deeply emotional, but much of it felt surface level for me. Most of the time it felt about as deep as a college admissions essay. It may also have been a book that would have been better read rather than listened to....more

It reminded me of later seasons of GOT, where the use of torture and rape of women seemed to be the only way to move the plot. Yes, these atrocities happened, and I’m not discounting that. I downloaded it and others from the library on my Kindle before the ice storm in case we lost power (because, you know, priorities). I didn’t realize it took place in Berkeley in the 1960s, and was semi-autobiographical. I appreciated it for being a YA book published in the ‘60s with a diverse cast of main characters. It was also a crazy time capsule of an era where 11 year olds pick up their 4 year old siblings from nursery school each day and all the kids run amok without parents until 6pm. title: Stiff: The Curious Lives of Human Cadavers
author: Roach, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Alternately fascinating and grisly. It does make you reflect on how we view our dead and our practices herein, and the numerous ways cadavers can be uAlternately fascinating and grisly. It does make you reflect on how we view our dead and our practices herein, and the numerous ways cadavers can be useful to advancing science and safety, if we could get past some of our squeamishness. As Roach says, it’s only in the last 100 years that going to a doctor reliably meant that you could get real help for some of what ails you — and cadavers are a part of those advances. And a reminder of the gross and horrifying alternatives that were concocted as medical care without better knowledge of the body and diseases. Roach has a funny writing style that also helps make the subject more palatable. It does make me reconsider what I would like done with my body when I die — beyond my planned organ donation. ...more

review: I’m ashamed to admit that I requested this from the library in no small part to hear Michelle Williams read the much written about parts with Justin TI’m ashamed to admit that I requested this from the library in no small part to hear Michelle Williams read the much written about parts with Justin Timberlake and Ginuwine. But I found this to be a devastating memoir of a girl/woman who, from age 3, has not been cared for or protected by the people who were supposed to love her. The number of people who profited off Spears, and her classic girl people-pleasing manner, created a gutting turn of events for her. I’ll never fully understand how no one who supposedly cared about her didn’t think to look into different legal representation for her in 13 years of conservatorship. And Spears does seem very gullible. But it feels like a cautionary tale for all women. And just go ahead a give Williams a Grammy and all the other awards for her reading — she earned them all. ...more

review: 3.5 stars. Listened to as an audiobook read by Prince Harry, and he's a very good narrator. He has very legitimate issues with his family, the press, 3.5 stars. Listened to as an audiobook read by Prince Harry, and he's a very good narrator. He has very legitimate issues with his family, the press, and the horrifying racist threats and comments he and Megan have endured. I know he's a prince, but you can't help but feel empathy for him and Megan, and the desire for privacy and to not be hunted like an animal. That said, sweet baby Jesus this book needed an editor. It clocked in at 16 hours, and it should have been 12 hours max. His message would have been more impactful if it had been tightened up. I also can't help feeling a bit sad, because this book is definitely "scorched earth" -- his issues with his family are real, but with this sort of tell-all book, you don't see how someone can go back to having a relationship with their sibling, parent, etc. after it. And maybe this sadness comes from being a mom, and knowing how much pain I would feel if my kids never spoke again. Everyone deserves peace and privacy, and I hope he finds a way to achieve it. ...more

title: Beneath a Scarlet Sky
author: Sullivan, Mark T.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have mixed feelings about this book. As I was reading it, I couldn't help thinking about the novel Forrest Gump -- the story of a man who happens toI have mixed feelings about this book. As I was reading it, I couldn't help thinking about the novel Forrest Gump -- the story of a man who happens to be in the right place at the right time, at multiple key moments in US history. Forrest Gump is a fiction novel. This book is "based on a true story," which increasingly falls into a grey category, where true life gets punched up for more cinematic flair. The author has said it's about 90% true, but there were -- for me -- too many instances where it just pushed the limits of credulity. About 2/3 through the book, I said to myself, "If at the end, Lella just so happens to walk into the square where Mussolini was strung up, I call bulls*it." And lo and behold (spoiler alert), not only does he just so happen to be walking by when he hears a commotion, and not only is he at the square, he witnesses the moment when he and Petacci's bodies are strung up and destroyed by an angry mob. It was the sixth or so "what are the odds?" moment I had in this book. It appears there are others who also question the veracity of the story, if you read some literary blogs. If it really did all happen to him, Lella lived an amazing and remarkable life, made to be put into film. And as fate would have it, the film rights were sold, and it will be a movie starring Tom Holland. And if he did even half of the things in the book, it's a remarkable life -- which is why I'm giving the benefit of the doubt and giving 3 stars. But this book demonstrates a trend I don't care for, of changing the truth to make for a better story -- which then isn't non-fiction. Let's hope I'm wrong and all of Lella's story is right....more

title: 84, Charing Cross Road
author: Hanff, Helene
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can't recall the last time I fell so hard and so fast for a book. It came on my radar thanks to the NYT Read Like the Wind newsletter, and it's the I can't recall the last time I fell so hard and so fast for a book. It came on my radar thanks to the NYT Read Like the Wind newsletter, and it's the sort of book I want to alternately cling to my chest and hand out to every single book lover I know. Read as an audiobook (and as charming as the written book must be, the actors reading it made it like a stage play and so infinitely better), it contains the correspondence between New York writer Helen Hanff and a small secondhand book shop in London, whom she writes to after seeing their ad in the paper and is looking for specific books. Going from 1949-1969, what starts as a more formal correspondence ends in deep love, friendship, and affection between people who never get to meet. It was also illuminating of life for ordinary people in the 1950s, when, for example, food rations persisted in Britain until 1952 (despite the war ending in 1945). I had no idea.Do you love stories about people who love books? This is for you. Do you love stories about unexpected cross-cultural friendships? This for you. Stories of intelligent, independent, forge-your-own-way- midcentury women? This is for you. Love New York? London? Funny Jewish women? You catch my drift. Do yourself a favor: check out this audiobook (or actual book) from your library, put aside 2 hours, and let this charming, joyful story wash over you. It's a dose of sunshine in winter. ...more

review: Listened to as an audiobook narrated by one of my favorite audiobook readers, Bonnie Turpin. Many of these essays should be required reading -- What WListened to as an audiobook narrated by one of my favorite audiobook readers, Bonnie Turpin. Many of these essays should be required reading -- What We All Lose and the In Alienable Rights of Women are particularly poignant. Thoughtful and thought provoking, these essays aren't a quick read or listen. They are meaty and sometimes difficult. That said, I found listening to 1-2 essays a day a way for me to listen and digest. For the bibliphiles, there is also a great essay about the "second shelf," meaning the place where female novelists who write Capital L literature are often relegated in a book store. And of how "genre literature" like romance and sci-fi/fantasy have been so much more embracing of female novelists. It made me reflect on my own reading each year, and I was surprised and embarrassed to see that each year, on average, only 1/3 of books I read are written by women. That's changing from now on -- at least 1/2 of all books I read each year will be by women, with a particular focus on the "second shelf."...more

review: 4.5 stars. A lovely, almost romantic memoir of a man, broken by the unexpected death of his brother at age 27, who quits his job at The New Yorker and4.5 stars. A lovely, almost romantic memoir of a man, broken by the unexpected death of his brother at age 27, who quits his job at The New Yorker and decides to become a security guard at the Met. It’s a reflection on the role of art, beauty, and history in our world, and our need to reflect and feel awe. It’s also a love letter to the people around us who do jobs and are often not seen. Yes, he doesn’t really touch upon the thorny legacy of museums like the Met, and how they acquired (or stole) some of their priceless pieces. But it’s a small quibble to a book that I just found genuinely lovely. If you’re the sort of person who looks to see what museums there are in a city before you visit, this book is for you. ...more

review: I worked at SF Opera for eight years, most of it in Development, so this  is a bit skewed. It's a quick diverting read, but Tarloff even notes aI worked at SF Opera for eight years, most of it in Development, so this  is a bit skewed. It's a quick diverting read, but Tarloff even notes at the end that he interviewed people who were leaders at SF Opera 20+ years ago and he diverted from what they told him was how things actually work. So he knows he's portraying things inaccurately. That was annoying, but creative license, whatever. But he also makes a point of Development being this person's job, so it was irritating to see it portrayed so wrong. Also, Toby never works. Like it's somehow acceptable for him to never be in the office, to never be at a performance, etc. He does have a lot of sex. As a former colleague said to me in reading the book : "I don't remember any afternoon trysts. I do remember a lot of board meetings and a lot of work in Excel."My other issue is this book feels like it was written 20+ years ago and didn't get picked up then. Tarloff tried to dust it off and submit it again in 2021, and this time it was accepted, but they didn't bother to make any real attempt to make it read like the era it is supposed to be taking place in (2022, post pandemic). All of these characters in their 40s have a landline phone. When Toby goes into the office, his assistant hands him pink slips with his messages. He talks of hot days in San Francisco needing AC (hahaha), and how easy it was for his daughter to get into UC Berkeley, the local college (comical even 20 years ago). There are literally two lines referencing the pandemic -- otherwise I would have thought it was taking place in 2000. There's creative license and then there's laziness. ...more

The quality of his writing is so intimate, observant, and even funny, andSimply put, Marra is one of the best writers I have read in the last decade. The quality of his writing is so intimate, observant, and even funny, and he makes characters that feel flawed and beautiful and real. I don’t think this story, as an overall story, is as compelling as A Constellation of Vital Phenomena. But it’s a story of immigrants and Americans in Hollywood in the throes of WWII, fleeing horrors only to experience new ones here — but all connected by a love of storytelling and a desire to make a better world. The story didn’t feel as fully realized as I would have liked, but I enjoyed it enormously nevertheless. ...more

title: Hollywood's Eve: Eve Babitz and the Secret History of L.A.
author: Anolik, Lili*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I first learned about Eve Babitz when I saw a picture of her playing chess naked with Marcel Duchamp. It was part of an art exhibition in LA a decade I first learned about Eve Babitz when I saw a picture of her playing chess naked with Marcel Duchamp. It was part of an art exhibition in LA a decade or so ago, and it stuck with me for two reasons: 1) This was definitely not the Duchamp I learned about in AP Art History; and 2) Her rather spectacular chest, coupled with her face completely obscured. It was like this ultimate reveal, alongside wanting to be discreet.When Joan Didion died earlier this year, I read a piece that referenced Eve Babitz, and how she and Joan were friends, but that they had very different takes on life in LA. I read Didion’s Play it As It Lays in college, expecting to love it because it was written by a fellow Cal alum, about my hometown of southern California. I felt betrayed by it. Yes, the writing was excellent. But it felt like Didion’s portrayal of LA was so shallow and one dimensional; it lacked the depth and nuance to which any person who actually lived there could attest. Babitz was mentioned in this article about Didion as a counterpoint – she was all the sex, drugs, and rock ‘n roll of the ‘70s in LA, but with a more authentic mix of LA thrown in.So I picked up this biography on Babitz, which is probably the only time I’ve read a biography about an author before actually reading anything by the author. Anolik is a Vanity Fair writer and an admitted superfan of Babitz, and her 2015 profile of Babitz led to Babitz’s books being reissued after being OOP for years. The book feels a bit too super fan at times, but she also helps give a lot of insights into Babitz’s writing I otherwise wouldn’t have had.In 2022, Babitz would be called a body positive, sex positive bisexual. In the ‘70s, she was often dismissed as a buxom LA girl, a bit of a floosy, and a starf*cker. Which is in fact not true, because she did have relationships with an enormous amount of celebrities – but she did before they were stars. Harrison Ford, Annie Leibowitz, Steve Martin, Ed Ruscha, Jim Morrison – she played a foundational role in their careers. Anolik calls all of the living past lovers up, and every one of them credited Babitz with some seminal piece of their image, their style, advice on their career, etc. She was more than a muse, and she has stayed friends with most of her numerous ex-lovers, never marrying. In fact, when she got second and third degree burns in a freak fire in the '90s, all of those friends and ex-lovers contributed $500K+ to her medical bills.Babitz’s father Sol was the first violinist of the LA Phil, as well as the first violinist of the MGM Studio Orchestra. Igor Stravinsky is her godfather. She and her sister Mirandi (with an equally fascinating life, though not a writer) successfully straddled the world of art, culture, and entertainment in LA, when the city often gets dismissed for only having one of those three.So now I go on to actually reading some of Babitz’s writing (most of which is labeled fiction, but is really non-fiction with the real people’s names changed), which I hope lives up to Anolik’s loving portrayal of a brilliant, difficult person who was written off for not being what most of America wanted to see in a woman in the ‘70s....more

review: 4.5 stars. Years ago I switched to only reading Sedaris via audiobooks. He's a phenomenal narrator of his own stories, landing jokes with surgical pre4.5 stars. Years ago I switched to only reading Sedaris via audiobooks. He's a phenomenal narrator of his own stories, landing jokes with surgical precision, but also providing critical and unvarnished emotion when the stories lean more towards pathos. As he has aged (and haven't we all), the pathos and tragedy of life has been more and more a part of his stories. The strained relationship and suicide of his sister Tiffany, his difficult and (to put it generously) unique father, who is now 96 and at the end of his life, and the challenges of the pandemic were front and center in this collection. As a writer, I marvel at his ability to balance humor and unflinchingly honest criticism on a knife's point. I can't think of another living writer who has made laugh out loud -- hard -- only to sucker punch me a few pages/beats later with a heartbreaking story about himself or others in his circle. We definitely have different viewpoints on some things, but having read all of his stories -- and in a way, growing up with him, even if he's 20 years my senior -- I appreciate the unvarnished, and often hilarious ways we looks at the relationships that will evolve and shift the most over the course of your life: those with your spouse and your family. ...more

review: 3.5 stars. It could be the way I read this, but sweet Jesus this book was tedious at times. I listened to it as an audiobook, and listened to the firs3.5 stars. It could be the way I read this, but sweet Jesus this book was tedious at times. I listened to it as an audiobook, and listened to the first 13 hours on two long car trips. I then had another six hours to listen to, trying to get 10 minutes here or there whenever I was driving alone. It took FOREVER. It’s the sort of story that is clever and brilliant at one turn, and then annoying and insufferable at the next. The author clearly subscribes to a “more is more is more” philosophy, and it felt needlessly convoluted and complicated at points. Were they trying to win an award for how many murder stories within a murder story they could uncover? My reactions to this book flung so widely that I don’t know if you asked me tomorrow if I felt 3.5 stars was accurate that I would answer the same....more

I read Morgenstern’s first novel, The Night Circus, mostly on a train ride in Spain years ago. It was a magical, immersive book — better than I could have hoped for a long ride. This book suffered from my having expectations for more of that magic. It had elements of it, but it desperately needed a better editor. It was 200 pages too long, with too many convoluted threads that couldn’t satisfyingly come together. I admire her creativity, ambition, and her attempted scale, but it just didn’t work nearly as well as it should have. ...more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** Beautifully written, fully realized characters and vivid writing. The love and connection between Theo and his mother, and the actio**spoiler alert** Beautifully written, fully realized characters and vivid writing. The love and connection between Theo and his mother, and the actions it motivates, are some of the best things in the book. That said, here’s my honest emotional journey with this 771 page book:Pages 1-200: This is So good, so rich, so heartbreaking. I can’t put it down. At times hard to read as a parent, and the idea of your child growing up adrift without you. Pages 200-400: Jesus, this poor kid. This life. And now the abusive father dies, so...yay? Freedom, yes, but now he’s an orphan and this is such an incredibly difficult life. Breaking my heart. Pages 400-600: Oh good, we are back in New York. And Hobie! Yay for Hobie!! Can I have more Hobie?And his life is getting better....and then his only childhood friend Andy dies?!? Must we just keep piling it on? Does this need to be this long?Pages 600-700: Boris is back...yay? The picture is actually gone, Kitsey is cheating on Theo, Pippa doesn’t love him, and Lucius Reeve is about to destroy him? Honestly, are we incapable of giving this character any happiness? Does this need to be this long? Isn’t there an editor for this book, anywhere?Pages 700-760: Murder, suicide attempt, he’s still marrying damn Kitsey. I swear to God, if Popchik the dog gets killed then there better be a John Wick twist to this book I didn’t see coming. I’m so frustrated because Tartt has made me care deeply about Theo but it’s almost feeling maudlin at this point. Pages 760-771: WTF? After 771 pages, this is the ending she’s come up with? This idiotic ‘life sucks and then you die’ monologue? Readers deserve better after committing this much time to this book....more

review: 3.5 stars. A lot of people I know love Kristin Hannah, and maybe this wasn’t the right choice for a first book to read by her. Or a book to read aroun3.5 stars. A lot of people I know love Kristin Hannah, and maybe this wasn’t the right choice for a first book to read by her. Or a book to read around Christmas. Many pulled quotes on the cover and back talk about it being an “epic story,” and it is, in the sense that it is big, long book. But it was also a slog at times, particularly because it started to feel like 500 pages of misery. I felt dread reading it. I don’t need (or even want) a book to be happy most of the time, but it bordered on misery porn meets Alaska Romeo and Juliet. It’s true that the happy ending that occurs in the last 15 pages of a 600 page novel felt hard fought for and hard won, and as a reader you can’t help thinking, “Finally, some joy for these people.” I guess I can say I appreciated the book while also not feeling much pleasure reading it....more

review: Two friends recently recommended this book to me, and one described it as “clutch it your chest when it’s done kind of wonderful.” It is. It’s the rarTwo friends recently recommended this book to me, and one described it as “clutch it your chest when it’s done kind of wonderful.” It is. It’s the rare sort of book that is funny, enjoyable, even kind of light for the first two thirds. Then, in its final act, it reveals itself to be elegant, wise, and authentically moving. I did not expect to love this book as much I did. The narrative style, the character development, the prose: utterly superb. The perfect summer read for someone who also wants to feel — and maybe lovingly clutch a book to their chest....more

review: On the surface, this should have been a slam dunk for me. A novel about a girl coming of age in San Diego while the world around her is, possibly endiOn the surface, this should have been a slam dunk for me. A novel about a girl coming of age in San Diego while the world around her is, possibly ending, because the rotation of the Earth is slowing? Sign me up. But this book ended being tiresome and frustrating. Walker never gives any of the characters any real emotional depth, so I never really cared about anyone. I see what she was trying to do — to show that to a 11-year old girl, it might feel more like the world is ending because the boy she likes isn’t talking to her, rather than the actual climate of the world changing and ending. But for an adult reader, it doesn’t land. Maybe it should have been tweaked to be for YA audience. I stick it out in the hope that the ending would improve my opinion. It didn’t. ...more

review: 3.5 stars rounded up. In recent years, with podcasts like Serial and Dirty John, I’ve found I enjoy true crime. However, this book showed me that what3.5 stars rounded up. In recent years, with podcasts like Serial and Dirty John, I’ve found I enjoy true crime. However, this book showed me that what I like is the puzzle element — the searching and sorting through clues, and trying to find answers. I don’t enjoy recounting all the lurid details of the crime. McNamara doesn’t go overboard and handles it reasonably well, but the sheer volume and type of crimes was disturbing with the Golden State Killer — more than 50 rapes, and 11 people killed. Hearing the details of so many was pretty unsettling, coupled with the fact that some of the crimes occurred only 30 minutes away from my house. I read as an audio book, and I definitely don’t recommend listening to it when you are home alone, at dusk. MacNamara is a talented writer and if she could have finished it before her untimely passing, I think it would have been 4-5 stars. It’s sad that she died before seeing the Golden State Killer arrested, when he and his crimes consumed so much of her life. ...more

review: 4.5 stars. In the course of reading this book, I stopped and read two other books (something I rarely do), but it kept calling me back. A book about a4.5 stars. In the course of reading this book, I stopped and read two other books (something I rarely do), but it kept calling me back. A book about a man accustomed to traveling and being in the world, who then finds himself sentenced to live in lifelong house arrest in a Moscow hotel following the Revolution — whose world was now so small — felt oddly fitting during SIP. What started as pleasant but perhaps a little slow evolved into a deeply felt book, both enjoyable and thoughtful. By the last act, I found myself looking forward to getting to read it each night. It took several unexpected turns that left me smiling at the end, having become very invested in the lives of Alexander and the occupants of the hotel. ...more

review: Listened to as an audiobook, which is my favorite way to read Sedaris. One of his better anthologies of late. Lots of laugh out loud funny stories, buListened to as an audiobook, which is my favorite way to read Sedaris. One of his better anthologies of late. Lots of laugh out loud funny stories, but also many filled with pathos. Sedaris reflects on getting older, the aging of his father, and his sister’s suicide. One story in particular involving his sister is warts-and-all ugly, showing the cruelty people can show to people they love. It does not reflect well on him, but I appreciate that he wrote it. You also find yourself pondering the relationship he has with his father; always fraught, but as he ages, is his response and (lack of) sense of responsibility appropriate? That said, lots of very, very funny stories — I won’t spoil them for you....more

review: I was 2/3 through this book when the news broke of Bourdain’s suicide. I would have been devastated no matter what, but this made it feel close and evI was 2/3 through this book when the news broke of Bourdain’s suicide. I would have been devastated no matter what, but this made it feel close and even eerie. The night before he died I had read his essay on addiction, and the eternal struggle to stay clean. title: Lincoln in the Bardo
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked up this book based on a rave  in Entertainment Weekly, and their specific recommendation to try the audio book. One of the things that I picked up this book based on a rave  in Entertainment Weekly, and their specific recommendation to try the audio book. One of the things that struck from the  was that Saunders was inspired by a single moment he learned of in Lincoln's life. Following the death of Lincoln's 10 year-old son Willie, it was said that Lincoln visited his son's body in its temporary internment place, and that Lincoln would pull his son's body from the coffin, hold it, and weep. That image stuck with Saunders for 20 years as the germination of a book. Perhaps it struck me because I have also carried around an idea for a novel based on one single moment in Lincoln's life. He's a remarkable template for a novel.This is a bizarre, brilliant, and unexpectedly moving novel, and an as aside, it is one of the best audiobooks I have ever listened to. I personally think it might be better than reading the novel. Much has been made of the fact that the audiobook has a cast of over 160 people, with the two leads being Nick Offerman (Vollman) and David Sedaris (Bevins), as well as the author Saunders as the Reverend. Bill Hader, Megan Mullally, Carrie Brownstein, Susan Sarandon, and Keegan Michael Key are some of the marquee names in it, most with bit parts. Because of the cast, I expected the book to be a comedy. I don't think it is, though it does have some funny moments. But Sedaris, Saunders, and especially Offerman are terrific. Offerman is best known for comedy but he brings a pathos and empathy to his reading that I wasn't expecting.The basic premise of the book is that when Willie Lincoln dies of typhoid, he goes to the 'bardo,' a Tibetan Buddhist concept of the place between the world of the living and afterlife. In it he meets a variety of characters, and the core thing is that none of them think they are dead -- merely sick. They are people who, for various reasons, cannot detach from their mortal life and are not prepared to move on. Indeed, when a host of angels comes to the Bardo periodically, trying to persuade these souls to move on, the inhabitants of the Bardo look on them as demons, trying to convince them they are dead when surely they are not. Children rarely stay in the Bardo -- they usually move on in a matter of minutes, or at most, a few hours. Willie Lincoln is different. When his father comes to visit his body in the mausoleum, he and his father share a moment, a connection between the two worlds, which has never happened before in the Bardo. It is fascinating to all of the inhabitants, and Willie does not want to move on -- he wants to be with his father.There is so much going on in this book, from the relationship between these spirits and their past lives to what is happening in the world of the living -- where Lincoln is in the thick of the Civil War and he cannot help but acknowledge how many sons are dying, and yet he cannot move on from the loss of his own. Saunders handles all of this brilliantly and empathetically.I will admit that the first 1-2 hours of the book were hard for me to get into. Saunders likes to use countless quotes -- some real, some made up -- to back up the story of what was actually happening to Lincoln in this moment in history. It was jarring and strange and there were moments where it felt like a hot mess. But once the narrative began to focus more on the Bardo, the story gelled for me, and shortly after that I couldn't put it down, so to speak. I found myself trying to listen to it every moment I could get.One of the places where Saunders is arguably most successful is in his telling of the relationship between Lincoln and Willie, and what Lincoln experiences at the loss of his son. Perhaps it's because I'm a parent now, but it taps into that deep, primal fear that every parent has of losing their child. That no one should ever have to bury their child. It goes against the natural order of things, and it is utterly soul crushing. On a personal level, it was heartbreaking to read. Add onto this that the person who lost their child is trying to lead a nation during a Civil War. He handles all of this so beautifully, so poignantly, that I find myself thinking of the book long after I stop reading it....more

title: The Man in the High Castle
author: Dick, Philip K.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Written in 1962 and taking place in the same year, The Man in the High Castle takes place in a San Francisco where the Nazis and the Japanese won WWIIWritten in 1962 and taking place in the same year, The Man in the High Castle takes place in a San Francisco where the Nazis and the Japanese won WWII. America has been divided into territories overseen by the Germans or Japanese, African-Americans have been forced back into slavery, Jews  and Africans have been all but exterminated, and the world lives in fear of nuclear war between Japan and Germany.This book would have been unsettling to read at any time, but to be reading it while the attack in Charlottesville occurred, as well as when a president makes claims of using "fire and fury like the world has never seen" regarding nuclear war with North Korea...honestly, I don't have words. This book resonated and disturbed me so profoundly, in no small part because a science fiction book written 55 years ago was becoming eerily relevant to my life today. In a way I never dreamed possible. In a way, I imagine, Dick himself might not have thought possible. Because I perhaps foolishly thought we were better.It's a brutal book, and not always easy to read or follow. The ending messes with your head and has you thinking long after you put it down. I can't say I enjoyed reading it, but I am grateful that I did. And in these times, it might be useful for others to read it, too....more

Like so many things, it's about expectations. I have literally moved this book across continents. I bought it in Vienna at the recommendation of another friend at the UN; I then moved it to CT, and then through two moves in CA. It took me 10 years to finally 'be in the mood' to read a book about Afghanistan. I'm not proud of this fact. My husband read this book 10 years ago and also really liked it. I found it interesting, but not as illuminating as I hoped and not as moving as others said it was. It's an incredible thing that Stewart did and accomplished by walking across Afghanistan, to be sure. But it felt like reading someone's daytimer. A factual recount of the activities of the day, with only periodic emotion, and writing that was ok but not great. I had expected more, and perhaps if my expectations hadn't been as high I might have liked it more....more

title: Swamplandia!
author: Russell, Karen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** Warning: spoilers ahead. If I'm being honest, this book feels like a short story idea that didn't have enough to it to be made into **spoiler alert** Warning: spoilers ahead. If I'm being honest, this book feels like a short story idea that didn't have enough to it to be made into a 400 page novel, but the effort was made nonetheless. On the surface it had so many elements I enjoy: a quirky family, an amusement park, perhaps something supernatural, a touch of Southern Gothic in the modern day. A family that runs a theme park dedicated to wrestling alligators in the Everglades is devastated by the death of their mother. If this book is supposed to be about anything, it's supposed to be about grief and how this family copes with it. One daughter believes she is communicating with ghosts and soon falls in love with one; the son goes to work for a competing, grotesque theme park about hell. The father goes to the mainland and leaves the children alone for literally months at a time. And then there is Ava, our 13 year old narrator observing it all.As I read the book I struggled to connect emotionally with these characters, which was surprising given that they were going through loss. But I kept going, particularly as daughter Ossie starts her regular communications with ghosts and reveals the story of the dead dredgeman whom she loves and plans to marry. When she runs away to marry him, and Ava meets a quirky man in the Swamp named the Birdman (dressed in feathers and long hair, hired to help remove the local buzzard population) who tells her he can bring her to the Underworld and save her sister, things get interesting. Is there really a supernatural world in the swamps? Did Ossie actually fall in love with the ghost and get spirited to the underworld?What follows is a swampish, Odyssey lite, one of many homages to Greek mythology in the book. Over the course of several days, the Birdman and Ava float and sail through the swamps, heading to the underworld, and the Birdman seems to have at least some altruistic thread in him, even if he is odd and there might something unhinged about him.And then things go sideways, literally and figuratively. The Birdman rapes 13 year old Ava, and she, in a bit of Stockholm Syndrome, thanks him afterward. This whole plot thread felt inconsistent with the characters and too August: Osage County -- needlessly titillating and scandalous, as if you can shock people enough then they won't notice the flaws in your plot and story. It infuriated me. What follows is Ava running way through the swamps, trying to survive and escape. When she and her sister are saved, it feels hollow because i don't have an emotional connection to them (when I should) and I feel like a pawn whom the author tried to shock into caring. It felt like a book about nothing except shock when it could have been a moving exploration of grief through the eyes of a child.The prose is strong, and this could be a a great short story, but it was ultimately unsatisfying....more

I think my biggest criticism of the book is the same criticism I had about the Martian: that I felt like I was reading a screenplay. Once I saw the bio of the author and saw he was a screenwriter, it became very clear that this was a book that was written to be a movie. I think it'll be a good movie, but it just didn't feel like a novel. author: Stegner, Wallace
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the second novel of Stegner's I have read, and it affirms for me his incredible talent for portraying the beautiful and imperfect relationshipThis is the second novel of Stegner's I have read, and it affirms for me his incredible talent for portraying the beautiful and imperfect relationships that shape each of our lives. Like Angle of Repose, this is a deliciously meaty read -- you do not read it quickly but instead savor it. It is also shorter, but no less impactful. Spanning 40 years, the novel focuses on two couples who become lifelong friends-- more than that, family. They are real, three-dimensional figures that you would actually see in life. title: Go Set a Watchman
author: Lee, Harper
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: NOTE: This  contains some spoilers. To be fair, I had no intention of reading this book, particularly after reading several s. But it was NOTE: This  contains some spoilers. To be fair, I had no intention of reading this book, particularly after reading several s. But it was given to me by a loved one, who told me that I should form my own opinions about it. So I did. This book was written before Lee wrote To Kill A Mockingbird, and wasn't an after-the-fact sequel. This fact is helpful when assessing the book. It also should be said that for 50+ years this book was not published while Lee was still of sound mind. Her sister, who managed her affairs after Lee's mind gave way, fiercely protected her. And then her sister died, and someone else took over Lee's affairs. And I truly believe that if Lee were of sound mind this would not have been published. She had 50+ years to do it and she never did, and I think for good reason. To me, it seems the motivations to publish were purely financial (and not to benefit her), and it forever changes her legacy.I believe I was given this book to read for the positives in it. Scout, now age 26 and living in New York, comes back to Maycomb on holiday and realizes for the first time how different her beliefs and values, particularly when it comes to racial equality, are from her lifelong friends and loved ones. Scout is a strong and passionate independent woman in the 1960s, and (one hopes) most readers will empathize with her struggle amidst the racism she sees around her, and her desire to have her own identity and own ideas and not just be someone's docile wife. And one could argue that the book paints a reasonably accurate picture of race relations and perceptions in the rural South in the 1960s, as awful as they were. It also becomes a story in which a child must recognize their parent as a flawed and imperfect human, and take them down from their pedestal. In those ways, this book has some merit.But it is the complete and utter degradation of the character of Atticus Finch and his seemingly newfound libertarian/state's rights/benevolent child perception of racism and race equality that gnaws at me without end. For me, Atticus Finch was and has been one of the most noble characters in all of literature. He's the sort of character people name their child after, in the hope that their child can emulate some of his most noble virtues. To see him as an older and yes, racist man, is devastating and also out of character with who he is To Kill A Mockingbird. The trial and his actions as a younger man are mentioned in the book, and Scout clearly believes that the same person who represented a one-armed black child accused of raping a white girl couldn't be the same racist older man. I feel the same. I feel like Lee wrote this manuscript to get a feel for her characters, and she told the story she wanted to tell when she wrote To Kill A Mockingbird. She dropped the microphone and peaced out after writing one great masterpiece. This book completely tarnishes that, and that saddens things for me. I fully admit to being one of those readers who loves the Atticus Finch of To Kill A Mockingbird. That book had a profound and lasting impact on me, not the least of which because this was a good, just, and noble man, a quietly unremarkable everyday hero who did the right thing because it was simply that -- the right and noble thing. I am actively choosing to ignore this novel in the legacy of Finch, and for Lee somewhat, too. ...more

Chandler is one of the original crime/mystery fiction writers, and he writes in the hard boiled noir style of a plucky detective, in this case in 1930s Hollywood. He practically created the genre, and some things that seem cliche you realize he invented, so he actually deserves a lot of credit. The crime and mystery itself were interesting, but I didn't quite anticipate the historical relativism I would have to use. I should have, but I didn't. Women are only there to be sexual enticements and sometimes devious objects (emphasis on objects) and sometimes in this world you have to knock women around from time to time to get them in line. review: "With books I practiced escapism, but it is also books that, in the end, led me back to my life. While reading can be deeply narcotic, it is also a dr"With books I practiced escapism, but it is also books that, in the end, led me back to my life. While reading can be deeply narcotic, it is also a drug that heals. For reading lifts us out of ourselves, and when we're returned, we're more empathetic, more capacious, wiser. I think reading can be a moral act." One of my favorite passages from this collection of letters from one friend to another as she prepares to have her first child. It really hit its stride in its last 50 pages. It's a testament to friendship, major life changes, and reading, and fittingly was given to me by a friend. Here's one other passage that stayed with me, from the author's perspective as writer: "I educated my soul through reading. I played with point-of-view, imagining other characters in the story, like my parents. Through this, I began to understand them, which softened me a little. As time went on I learned how events create plot, so when I felt that because my father had made a mess of his life I was bound to make a mess of mine or marry someone who'd mess it up for me -- well, eventually I had to admit this plot lacked the "inevitability" of a thoughtfully designed story. I understood at last I really could choose my own ending."Strangely, one of the largest takeaways for me from this book was the hope that if I have a child, I hope they love reading as much as I do. ...more

title: A Tree Grows in Brooklyn
author: Smith, Betty
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those books that I have always meant to read and never got around to until now. I was prompted by an NPR Fresh Air interview I heard, iThis is one of those books that I have always meant to read and never got around to until now. I was prompted by an NPR Fresh Air interview I heard, in which the guest (author of a recent book on The Great Gatsby) talked about how these two books were almost forgotten when first published, but they gained a remarkable second life as part of the books for soldiers program in WWII. The publishers of Gatsby and A Tree Grows in Brooklyn gave thousands of free copies of the books to soldiers oversees as part of a government's armed services editions (made to fit into a pocket), and they were two of the most popular titles amongst soldiers, which I think says a lot about stories and themes resonated with soldiers at that time.It's a book that more or less chronicles the childhood of Francie Nolan, the semi-autographical character based on the author Betty Smith. Long before Brooklyn was a hip enclave, it was a working class neighborhood full of poor immigrants who made it on determination, gumption, and a little luck to get their slice of the American dream. It's so fully realized that you feel as if you are there, and while not a great deal happens in the book, you find yourself invested in Francie in her life. I couldn't help but find parallels between this and the recent film "Boyhood."It's a book to be read at a leisurely pace, and when it's done you know that Francie Nolan will stick with you long after....more

title: Yes Please
author: Poehler, Amy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: To be fair, I would give this two and a half stars if I could. I love Amy Poehler, and so it pains me to give the book a mediocre . Throughout tTo be fair, I would give this two and a half stars if I could. I love Amy Poehler, and so it pains me to give the book a mediocre . Throughout the book Poehler complains about not having enough time to write a book because she is so busy, and in a way it comes through in the content and depth of her book. It's not especially funny (not that it needed to be), but what I was really disappointed by was how surface level it was. She never goes into great depth or tells especially personal stories anywhere. For example, in her chapter about being a cofounder of Upright Citizens Brigade (UCB), she talks about how UCB goes from being a small improv group in New York to a massively successful, even accredited education program in two cities and whose promise is to never raise ticket prices over ten dollars. She explained this all in one paragraph. One. I sat there thinking, "This is interesting. How did you do this? What where the challenges, etc?" But she had already moved to another surface level discussion. Similarly, the chapter about Parks and Rec primarily consists of short paragraphs about each actor in which, like a People magazine column, she says what she likes best about each actor and one sentence about the time they made her laugh the hardest. That's it. She also never goes into personal details and never says a bad thing about anyone, which is commendable in its own way. But again, it felt so surface level to rarely go into any emotional detail. The chapter about her divorce from Will Arnett was so complimentary that I literally had to google any reasons as to why they broke up, because the way she writes it I couldn't see why they weren't together. By all accounts they split because they simply weren't in love with one another anymore, and all she needed to say was that. It's not bad mouthing and perhaps it would be hard to say, but it would have felt more honest. I was struck reading parts of this book because when Poehler writes about Tina Fey, she always talks about Tina writing whenever she had a moment. I hate to make the comparison (because I don't think it's fair and people never compare the books of two male comedians), but I couldn't help thinking that Tina's love of writing shone through in her memoir. I just don't think Poehler did have the bandwidth (or perhaps the passion) to write a memoir. And finally (and this is a criticism of the publisher, not her), the book was printed on high-gloss heavy paper, and as a result the damn thing weighed four pounds even though it was 300 pages. It was ridiculous, and I know I am a Luddite who still reads printed books, but come on. It felt like another way the publisher tried to give more substance to a book that didn't have as much to it as it should. ...more

review: If I could give this book 4 1/2 stars, I would. It deserves one of those big titles like "a great American novel," or more specifically, a uniquely AmIf I could give this book 4 1/2 stars, I would. It deserves one of those big titles like "a great American novel," or more specifically, a uniquely American novel. At it's core it's the story of a marriage (or in some ways, two marriages), but it's also the story of one family's life in the American West, and how it shapes them. The promise and hope that brought so many people out west, and the challenges that they faced once they got here. Stegner is a terrific writer, and while the book doesn't move quickly, it's the kind of novel you can sit for long periods with on a couch or hammock and lose yourself in. It's heartbreaking and moving and feels very authentic and real. If I had one criticism of the book (and why it isn't five stars) it's the ending. Stegner chooses to have the narrator, Lyman Ward, end the biography of Lyman's grandmother Susan Ward (around whom much of the book revolves) after a very specific moment in her life. It's a heartbreaking moment, but I found myself yearning to know more about their life after that moment. I imagine Stegner wants you to fill in the details, but it felt somewhat unfinished to me-- or rather that after writing 600 pages, he thought he needed to cut it short or else the book would be 1,000 pages. ...more

review: I had been told this was a tear-jerker, and when I started crying at page 116, I knew it to be true. title: The King of Elfland's Daughter
author: Dunsany, Lord
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: WARNING: This  contains SPOILERS. Lots of spoilers. I should begin this  by saying that I wanted to like this book. On paper, I should havWARNING: This  contains SPOILERS. Lots of spoilers. I should begin this  by saying that I wanted to like this book. On paper, I should have. And I tried to have some degree of historical relativism while reading it, but honestly the whole book was so maddening I could hardly stand it. There is NO character development whatsoever -- none. Aside from this, I'll try to detail out just some of the things that I think go wrong with it:1) The very premise of the book is flimsy and unengaging. 12 men go to the king and say "We want magic so that people will remember our boring and unremarkable country for something. Send your son to a magic land so we can have some magic (no one, by the way, brings up the fact that someone magical already lives in their mist -- the female witch Zoorenderel, who enchants the sword and then basically raises the child (Orion) that Alveric and Lirazel have. Which is good, because these two suck at being parents. But she's a woman, so she couldn't possibly have value beyond this.)2) King of Erl's son Alveric goes to Elfland and takes the daughter, who has no redeeming value other than that she is pretty. In fact, this is a theme throughout the novel. She has no depth, no character, and all she cares about is staying young and pretty. And I guess she bore him an heir, but the child, for her, is an afterthought at best. 3) Let's be honest: Alveric and Lirazel aren't exactly meant for each other. They have nothing to connect on (not even their child), and when the King of Elfland steals his daughter back, don't you just think, "Good. They weren't really working out so maybe this is for the best." But no, I'm supposed to believe that there is some great love there, when LITERALLY all they have talked about is how they don't do anything together and she won't pray to Alveric's gods and it makes him so angry. So naturally he's going to go on this long quest to find her.4) AND THEN THEY START KILLING UNICORNS. It's a truth universally acknowledged that someone who kills unicorns is a bad person, right? At least, that's what Legend taught me as a kid. But here Orion, the 14-year old kid who has been raised by a witch because his parents have been MIA for 10 years hunts unicorns for sport. No other reason, just to kill them and mount their heads on walls. How is this my hero? And what is the point of this in the story??5) Alveric knowingly puts two legitimately insane people in charge of his quest to find Elfland (which, by the way is perhaps the most boring quest in the history of fantasy novels). This says a lot about the novel. It also gives the author a reason to drag out this flimsy story line ever further. He deserves to wander around for 12 years without finding anything. 6) Does anyone else find it weird that a grown woman (who has in fact had a child of her own) sits on her father's lap in Elfland all day long???7) The 12 men who asked for magic in Erl get it and then realize that they don't want it after all. They go to the person in the kingdom who had magic THE WHOLE TIME and she at least tells them that they are stupid and this happening. Deal with it. 7) The tedious, boring story is finally ended by Lirazel asking her father to give up all his magic so she can go back to earth. He does and brings the magic to earth, so that her son can go on happily killing unicorns until the end of his days.Did I also mention how over-the-top flowery the language is? Not a bad thing in the right hands, but in this case it just felt ever more tedious. If I read the phrase "the fields we know" one more time I was going to throw the book against the wall.Finally (and this is not a criticism of the actual book), even my physical edition of the book was ridiculous. My copy was published in 1977, clearly try to ride on the coattails of the increase in Tolkien's popularity, and the cover shows a pretty elf with perky, hard-nippled breasts walking around a field -- because again, the only thing a female character can do is be pretty or raise children. And I'll spare you the copy on the back of the book (it's a doozy), but it's starts with, in bold, "Happily NEVER After."I had to buy the book because it's been out of print for years and not even the SF Public Library carried it. I think the fact that it's no longer is print is probably a good thing. ...more

review: I’m not quite sure what to say about this book. I didn’t find it to be shockingly sexually explicit, but I also didn’t find the book erotic – though II’m not quite sure what to say about this book. I didn’t find it to be shockingly sexually explicit, but I also didn’t find the book erotic – though I don’t know if erotic is what Murakami was going for. If anything, I found the book to be quite melancholy. It’s a sad book about sad and unhappy people who have a hard time letting the past release its grip on them. I don’t say that as a criticism but more as a matter of fact. I wasn’t exactly excited to pick it up at the end of a long day because it often made me sad reading it, and I also didn’t have much emotional engagement with the characters. Again, not a prerequisite because I’ve read other books where I didn’t really connect with the characters and I still enjoyed them. But I found the supporting character Reiko to be by far the most interesting character, and I would almost have rather had the book be about her. It’s definitely well-written, and there are moments when I thought the writing was genius. It’s his first book and I’d be curious to read one of his more famous novels to see if I can connect with it better....more

title: Deep Nutrition: Why Your Genes Need Traditional Food
author: Shanahan, Catherine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Truthfully, I would give this 2 1/2 stars if I could. This was given to me by a good friend's Mom, and there are some very compelling, well researchedTruthfully, I would give this 2 1/2 stars if I could. This was given to me by a good friend's Mom, and there are some very compelling, well researched, and interesting ideas in here - not all of them new. Shanahan believes that our bodies need food more similar to our ancestors - whole foods, minimal processed foods and little sugar, avoiding vegetable oils, and frankly eating more nutrient rich foods like offal and meat on the bone and homemade stocks. She also contends that you should eat more fats like those in nature - like whole milk instead of skim - in moderation, because they are less processed and can provide more nutrients. She also is a big proponent for eating these sorts of foods while pregnant to give a child a nutritional leg up. But some of her other ideas I found at best lacking enough scientific evidence, and at worst kind of preposterous. She believes that doing all of these things will make you produce a more beautiful child with more symmetrical features, straight teeth, high cheek bones - and they won't ever get chronic diseases. Basically the answer to all your problems in life seem to come from this way of eating, and I just need well researched scientific data to believe it. Her best ideas have solid research to back them up, and I put them in the 'can't hurt, might help' category that I am totally up for trying. Well intentioned but I just need more evidence to believe half of what she proposes. ...more

title: The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay
author: Chabon, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s funny, I first picked this book up 12 years ago while I was still in college. I read about 100 pages and couldn’t get into it and put it down forIt’s funny, I first picked this book up 12 years ago while I was still in college. I read about 100 pages and couldn’t get into it and put it down for another day. I’ve met at least three other friends who are around the same age who did the exact same thing. Looking at the book now, 12 years later, I think I needed to be older in order to fully appreciate this incredible, incredible novel. 12 years ago I had never been to Prague or even New York City, and didn’t know what a golem was. Now, having been to these places and living on the East Coast for two years )and being in NYC at least once a week for work or fun), it’s a city that feels a bit like home to me. And this book is a love letter to New York, to be sure, as well as to the romance and power of comics, graphic novels, the written word, and any form of art that lets you express yourself and work out your demons and who you are. It’s interesting that Kavalier and Clay was published in 2000, before September 11. In a weird way I could see this book being written as a response to 9/11.Long story short, I haven’t loved a book like I love this book in a long time. It’s wonderfully written, well-paced, well developed, well-researched, alternately funny and gut-wrenchingly heartbreaking – it really is genius and deserving of the Pulitzer Prize. The relationships between every character felt plausible and real, especially between the three protagonists Joe Kavalier, his cousin Sam Clay, and the love of Joe’s life, Rosa Saxs. And even the comic book characters and story lines that Kavalier and Clay come up (genius stories-within-a story) are great and completely believable as comic book tales of the 1930s and 1940s. I’m half surprised Chabon hasn’t created graphic novels of the Escapist and the Luna Moth (two of the comics featured in the story) since publishing K&C. I’ll admit that this book contained numerous slam-dunk plot points that were probably going to make me enjoy it no matter what: magic, comic book tales of adventure and escape, WWII, a Jewish boy in New York, and love. But Chabon manages to elevate the story, making it feel like something worthy of big titles like “the great American novel.” He’s too clever by half, and if I noted all the moments where I reflected on how incredibly talented he is while reading the book, we’d be here all night. It’s his masterpiece. He may write other great novels, but it’s hard for me to imagine that anything could be more fulfilling than Kavalier and Clay. As I got to the end, after 650 pages, I genuinely didn’t want it to end. And maybe that is the highest praise of all....more

title: Fat Chance: Beating the Odds Against Sugar, Processed Food, Obesity, and Disease
author: Lustig, Robert H.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I first heard Dr. Lustig, a UCSF physician/researcher, on our local NPR station, and he got me intrigued to read his book. Lustig has been one of the I first heard Dr. Lustig, a UCSF physician/researcher, on our local NPR station, and he got me intrigued to read his book. Lustig has been one of the most vocal critics of added sugar and processed food, and what he seeks to do in this book is explain how our bodies process and metabolize sugar, and how our increased consumption over the past 30 years has contributed to the obesity epidemic worldwide. To be clear, he only criticizes added sugar, not naturally occurring sugar in fruits, vegetables, and milk, particularly because eating fruits and vegetables gives you the benefit of fiber. And that's really what the moral of his story is: eat lots more fiber, eat far less added sugar and processed food, and don't drink your calories (via soda, juice, sweetened beverages, etc). He talks about the various diets popular over the past 30 years and why they have (or haven't) worked, and what, purely from a health perspective (and not a weight-loss perspective) will help you combat chronic diseases. And that's one of the things I liked about the book -- he isn't selling a weight-loss diet at the end; he's just trying to educate the lay person on the complex biology of how our body processes food, and that 'a calorie is not a calorie.' He discusses the role of physical activity, genetics, etc, and he does a fairly scathing indictment on our food policies today, and a lot of it is things you've heard before. But he really has written a manifesto on things you can change in your diet to make you healthier (though perhaps not thinner) to combat diseases like cancer, diabetes, and heart disease. And sadly, he explains from an evolutionary perspective why the fat on your thighs and hips is so freaking hard to lose.My one criticism is that his writing style can be obnoxious from time to time (if you know a high-level doctor, well, you know the personality I speak of). It might put some people off, but if you ignore that and really just read the pure scientific facts, I think it's a super worthwhile read....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked up this book because EW said it was hilarious and gave it an ‘A,’ but for me it was super mediocre. The premise of the novel is kind of funnyI picked up this book because EW said it was hilarious and gave it an ‘A,’ but for me it was super mediocre. The premise of the novel is kind of funny: working in the theatre in 1930s Berlin, the main character finds himself single-mindedly focused on sleeping with a girl from his youth whom he runs into years later and finds that her ugly duckling has now become a swan. He follows her all over the world, in the process just misses any number of terrible things happening in Europe at the time on his desperate quest to get laid by her. It’s an amusing idea but its effectiveness wears thin after about 50 pages. The rest of the book is a jumble of half-genres and I found it to be a mess. First, there isn’t really any teleportation in this book or anything especially sci-fi, in spite of its title (I will admit I only skim book s because I still want to be surprised, so this could be my own damn fault). It’s not a romance or a historical fiction, either, and for a book so focused on getting laid, there’s little of it. And it’s not especially funny. On top of all of this, it moves SUPER slow, which any book that bills itself as a lighthearted comedy sure as hell shouldn’t be. Perhaps if I was a guy who was obsessed with sleeping with this one particular girl and because of this I hadn’t gotten laid in five years, I would find this book absolutely amazing. It makes me wonder if the EW er fits this bill. But I was seriously disappointed by it. ...more

title: Little Bee
author: Cleave, Chris*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have an almost uncanny ability to bring the absolute wrong books on vacation. Particularly if it’s a trip to a tropical destination, or a trip to a I have an almost uncanny ability to bring the absolute wrong books on vacation. Particularly if it’s a trip to a tropical destination, or a trip to a developing country (for example, reading “Fingersmith” in Costa Rica, “Corelli’s Mandolin” in Italy, “The Lost Child” in Czech Republic, etc). I brought this book because a good friend recommended it a few years ago, and the back-of-the-book synopsis intentionally reveals very little about the story. In fact, if there is a Mad Men-esque publishing award for the most effective book cover language for book sales, whoever did it for “Little Bee” deserves a medal. I won’t spoil too much of the story for anyone who intends to read it, but this book is DEPRESSING. Which isn’t to say that it isn’t a good story (it is) and one that people should read (particularly those who are less informed about what happens to women in developing countries, and to immigrants coming to the West for asylum). That’s all I will say about the plot. But it hit for me on several of the things I have the hardest time dealing with emotionally, and here I was in one of the most beautiful places on Earth (Iguazu Falls) and it made me want to throw myself over them. I think I need to actively seek out some certified ‘beach reads’ for vacations from now on. ...more

review: Mitchell is easily one of the most talented writers I’ve come across in a long time. It’s a gorgeously written book, and from the very first page you Mitchell is easily one of the most talented writers I’ve come across in a long time. It’s a gorgeously written book, and from the very first page you know as a reader that you’re in a very, very capable hands. I guess the only reason why I give this book four stars instead of five is that I found it to be so damn depressing at times. In fact, after finishing the first part, I remarked to my friend Russell (who loaned me the book), “It’s so good, but I have such a hard time reading about all of these things that happen to Jacob. And then, when I already think it’s pretty depressing, it gets worse in part II!” I guess it comes down to the pleasure factor. I don’t need a happy ending per se, but I almost felt weighed down by the book at times. It also felt like the last major segment of the book (involving the English frigate the Phoebus) introduced too many new story lines and narratives, and that it weakened the overall plot of the novel. Once it was done the reader only had about 8 pages in which Mitchell tried to tie up the many other beautiful loose ends he had unraveled over the course of the story. But it does make me want to pick up “Cloud Atlas.” There is no question that he is an exceptional writer....more
