title: The Apprentice: My Life in the Kitchen
author: Pépin, Jacques
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Some people learned to cook from Julia Child. I learned from Jacques Pepin. I first met Jacques Pepin when I was a college intern at KQED and they werSome people learned to cook from Julia Child. I learned from Jacques Pepin. I first met Jacques Pepin when I was a college intern at KQED and they were filming one of his television programs. The entire studio smelled absolutely amazing, and I was allowed to sneak into the filming and watch from the corner. After the taping ended, as was customary, the crew got to come in and eat the delicious food he had made. I hung in the shadows in the back (not being part of the crew), and Jacques Pepin came over and basically poo-pooed any notion of me NOT eating with them. I got to ask him some questions on how he did certain things (like chopping the onion…as some of you know I did not come from a house where my Mom took pleasure in cooking, so all basic cooking skills were essentially foreign to me). He demonstrated for me and answered my questions, and it was only when I was older and I realized just who this charming French man was that I realized what an incredibly special moment I had been granted.In a time when food is practically fetishized on TV and in popular culture but little ‘cooking’ and practical cooking skills are actually taught, Jacques Pepin is one of the exceptions. I have learned SO MUCH from his books and TV programs – real, honest-to-goodness practical skills that I use every day. And he taught me a lot about adapting and improvising recipes, flavors that pair well together, etc, so that I never feel wedded to follow a recipe verbatim. His life story is an impressive one, and his autobiography was an enjoyable read from start to finish. From living through WWII bombings as a child on a farm in Lyon, to being the chef to Charles DeGaulle, and later being Julia Child’s culinary partner in crime, he’s had a remarkable career. The book is called “My Life in the Kitchen,” so I guess I should not be disappointed that the book spends far less time on his personal life. But I was, especially because his family often appears in his cooking shows. In his own way, though, it seemed a bit ‘French’ to guard your private life to some degree, so I guess in the end I accept it. A really enjoyable read from start to finish. ...more

title: All the King’s Men
author: Warren, Robert Penn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Holy goodness this is a great book. If you’ve heard anything about this novel before picking it up, you’ve likely heard that it’s one of the great novHoly goodness this is a great book. If you’ve heard anything about this novel before picking it up, you’ve likely heard that it’s one of the great novels on American politics. And it is – the story of the rise and fall of Willie Stark and the backroom political dealings sadly feel as timely and relevant today as they did back in the 1930s. But what we really struck me about this book was the astonishingly beautiful prose. It is pure poetry on the page (reading the book sleeve was when I realized Warren was our first poet laureate), and the book is about so much more than politics. It’s about the relationships that define who you are for your entire life, and the moments that do as well. I dog-eared and underlined so many pages I almost felt like I was in college again. I have to wonder that if I read this book while in my freshman year at Cal if I would have ended up a Poli Sci major. The only thing I had a hard time swallowing while reading it was its liberal use of the ‘n word’ and a variety of derogatory comments about other ethnicities. I realize it’s completely to the period of 1930s Louisiana, but rivaled “Django Unchained.” Another book completely and utterly worth reading before you die....more

title: The Iliad: A New Translation
author: Homer
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After reading “Song of Achilles” and seeing “An Iliad” it felt like it was about time I got back to the original source material and read “The Iliad” After reading “Song of Achilles” and seeing “An Iliad” it felt like it was about time I got back to the original source material and read “The Iliad” for the first time. This particular translation had been positively ed on the book jacket for “Song of Achilles” and I thought a more modern translation might make it more accessible. The funny thing is, the more modern language seemed to strip away some of the poetry. It’s still a remarkable (and epic) piece of literature, but it didn’t seem to have the more lyrical quality I expected. As for the story itself, it is as timeless and heartbreaking now as it was thousands of years ago. It shows all sides of war, and how there are people who love the ‘heroes’ on both sides. Every person is a son, husband, father. When Priam comes to Achilles and begs him to return Hector’s body, kissing Achilles hands and telling him that no father has ever had to kiss the hands of the man who killed his children, it’s still devastating. It’s a book worth reading before you die. ...more

title: The End of Your Life Book Club
author: Schwalbe, Will*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What can I say other than read this book. As I finished it, with tears streaming down my face, I was grateful that I finished it while at home, and noWhat can I say other than read this book. As I finished it, with tears streaming down my face, I was grateful that I finished it while at home, and not on public transit (hence avoiding being THAT WEEPING GIRL on the bus). Simply put, this is the memoir of Will Schwalbe’s last two years with his mother, a dynamic and remarkable woman who was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in 2007 and passed away in 2009. Schwalbe was editor in chief at a major publishing house, and books had always been one of the things that they connected on. You may think a book with this story would be depressing, but in fact it’s hopeful and quite beautiful. It highlights the role books play in our lives, the way that they can get us to talk about themes, ideas, philosophies, opinions, and life experiences in a way few other mediums can. Conversations you never thought you would have with someone can stem from discussing a novel. They can bring you closer together and expose to you the soul of the person you are speaking with – and under the circumstances of a terminal cancer diagnosis, they can provide the bridge to some of the more meaningful conversations one can have. In many ways, this book is love letter to the power of the written word."The End of your Life Book Club" also touches on the universal themes of love between a parent and child, creating relationships with your parents when you are an adult, caring for those that are ill, friendships from all walks of life, and the impact and legacy you want to have on the world. Mary Anne Schwalbe had a wonderful career and did remarkable things for students and refugees, but to her the greatest achievement of her life were her children, grandchildren, and 40+ year marriage. They were the legacy she would leave behind.This book also doesn’t shy away from illness and death, which seems to be almost taboo in our culture anymore. In a scene that really struck with me, Mary Anne has decided to throw a medium-sized birthday party for herself, a year and a half into her pancreatic cancer diagnosis. People kept asking her if it was a good idea – "Won’t it tire you out? Are you physically up to it?" – and she just smiled and said “This is my last birthday party.” She didn’t say it in a sad or angry way, but rather decided that she was going to have a wonderful time surrounded by the people she cared about. She couldn’t change the cancer, but she could embrace that night as one of the most special of her life. I guess I hope that if I were dying of cancer and knew this would be my last birthday, I would do the same. ...more

title: The Irregulars: Roald Dahl and the British Spy Ring in Wartime Washington
author: Conant, Jennet
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was reminded of this book when I saw “Skyfall.” I had read a few s of it in Time and elsewhere when it first came out in 2008 and it almost soI was reminded of this book when I saw “Skyfall.” I had read a few s of it in Time and elsewhere when it first came out in 2008 and it almost sounded like the best sort of cocktail party trivia: Did you know that beloved children’s author Roald Dahl was a British intelligence spy during WWII, charged with bringing isolationist America into the fight? And that Ian Fleming and others were a part of it, too? Man, this is my JAM.But unfortunately, if you’re expecting Bond-ian levels of espionage and intrigue, don’t read this book. The reality is that we don’t really know much at all about what Dahl actually did during the war, other than he worked for British intelligence and was in charge of pushing pro-British propaganda and spinning stories that would make Americans consider entering into another world war. Dahl was a RAF pilot, that much is true, and he did technically get injured in a plane crash while in service, but the reality is that he crashed his plane because it was a model he wasn’t familiar with – not because he was in enemy combat. Being the great writer we all know him to be, he spun a great tale super loosely based on the truth, and he became a successful propagandist for the war. If this is a book about anything, it’s about the use of propaganda and spin during the war.It’s also painfully slow and often boring. Conant name-drops at least 200 people who are impossible to keep straight and she does little to remind you of who someone is from time to time if she already told you who they are 100 pages ago. And lastly, I stopped counting at the fifth grammatical/spelling typo in the book. Call me crazy, but if you’re writing a non-fiction book where you are intending to show me a long-hidden truth, it becomes harder for me to believe in you when you or your editors have seemingly little eye for accuracy or attention to detail. The fact that Dahl worked for British intelligence during WWII is an interesting factoid. Alas, for me, with little more than that to go on, it does not make a satisfying book. ...more

title: State of Wonder
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book reaffirms why Patchett is one of my favorite living authors. When so many popular books today are genre books or serialized series, PatchettThis book reaffirms why Patchett is one of my favorite living authors. When so many popular books today are genre books or serialized series, Patchett consistently produces beautiful stand-alone books. She's a great storyteller -- you can sit down with one of her books and get immediately sucked in, reading 50 pages in a sitting and not realizing you've done so because she didn't do it with gimmicks or little end of chapter hooks. She also has a fantastic ear for voices, and in turn creates solid, well-formed characters that are completely distinct from one another."State of Wonder" is the tale of Marina Singh, a 40-something Minneapolis doctor working at a pharmaceutical company who learns that her friend and longtime office mate has died while trying to get some information about one of the company's drug development projects in the Amazon. Marina reluctantly goes to Brazil to get an idea of what happened to him, to get some closure for her and his family, and to learn more about the secret project. That's all I'll give away about it, but the novel delves into some interesting ethical questions about the role of medicine, a Westerner's role amongst indigenous people, and a lot more. It's an intelligent and engaging read, and yet also perfect to read on a beach. ...more

review: I have a feeling that if I read this book as a kid, it would undoubtedly be a five-star book for me. My quibbles with it are those of an adult reader I have a feeling that if I read this book as a kid, it would undoubtedly be a five-star book for me. My quibbles with it are those of an adult reader (it's closer to three and a half stars for me), but I imagine that reading this as a kid is a really empowering thing. It's a book designed for the smart kids, one that tells them that it's ok to be different and intelligent and not fit in. I wished that the ending didn't clean up so neat and tidy in the last 10 pages, that it wasn't so formulaic at times, and as an adult I found the relationship of Ender and Valentine, towards the end, to be a little suspect and possibly veering out of filial love territory. title: Possession
author: Byatt, A.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: To me, there's always been something a little bit odd about people who spend their entire lives researching the lives of others. I'm not saying it's aTo me, there's always been something a little bit odd about people who spend their entire lives researching the lives of others. I'm not saying it's a bad thing, but it strikes me odd that someone would devote their life to learning the in's and out's of how someone else lived their life...all the while not really building up a life of their own. This put me at odds with the protoganists of "Possession," two perfectly fine but bland academics who minutely research the lives and writings of two Victorian poets. The poets themselves were also perfectly fine but not especially likable. In fact, none of the four principal protaganists are people I liked very much. I don't have to like them, but I do have to care about them. And I had a hard time doing it over the course of this 600-page novel.On a technical level, you can see why Byatt won the Booker Prize for the novel. She does a tremendous job creating two authentic Victorian poets -- writing 'their' poetry, their short stories, all of it -- in addition to creating the two modern day academics who uncover the previously unknown connection between the two poets. It's believable, and Byatt is talented. And the novel does evoke much of Victorian romanticism. But while I can appreciate the technical skill used to create the novel, I can't say I took much pleasure reading it. I just wasn't invested in any of these characters, or the 'villains.' I can see how Byatt is trying to show the struggle of a Victorian woman trying to be financially independent and having a literary career of her own, but still... it just didn't do it for me. ...more

But all my complaining aside, it’s an amazing book, and one that I don’t regret reading (or even slogging through) for one second. I really can’t do it justice in a , mainly because I have waited so dang long to write something up. But I can see why it’s called the greatest work ever written by an American. There are moments of clarity and relevance in it that resonate as much today as it did when it was initially written. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I absolutely loved the concept of this book – the idea of two cities, one rich and one poor, in the former Soviet bloc, literally beside one another (I absolutely loved the concept of this book – the idea of two cities, one rich and one poor, in the former Soviet bloc, literally beside one another (and in many cases overlapping), but citizens of each city are forbidden to look at one another. They must constantly ‘unsee’ what is in front of them, or fear getting taken by ‘Breach,’ never to be seen again. There is the literal interpretation of this – the gentrified city of Prague beside the more rough-around-the-edges Budapest, for example – or the more figurative. I could see parallels between the idea in the book and my own life; the particular neighborhood of SF that I work in is Hayes Valley, an affluent hipster enclave that’s been gentrified and tony for the past five years or so. Surrounding Hayes Valley is Civic Center/Tenderloin, a scruffy neighborhood plagued by crime and homelessness. The neighborhoods co-exist and in many ways overlap, but you often choose not to see each other – or more specifically, you choose to ‘unsee’ all of the blight.Perhaps it is because I loved the premise so much that my expectations were too high, and as a result the actual storyline let me down. Don’t get me wrong – it’s a perfectly entertaining read – but I wanted to the reveal at the end of the murder mystery to be more interesting, more nuanced. It ended up feeling like a run-of-the-mill murder mystery, albeit in a fascinating setting. Maybe I’m not giving it all the credit it deserves, but it was a respectable three stars....more

title: The Omnivore's Dilemma: A Natural History of Four Meals
author: Pollan, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If I could give it 4.5 stars, I would. This is a much longer  than I typically write, but it’s a book that deserves more in-depth discussion. I If I could give it 4.5 stars, I would. This is a much longer  than I typically write, but it’s a book that deserves more in-depth discussion. I think it comes as no surprise to anyone who knows me that I’m the target audience for this book – urban Bay Area foodie, curious to learn more about the environmental and public health costs of our typical food decisions. I’d read “Fast Food Nation,” seen documentaries like “King Corn.” I thought I ‘got’ it. But I was really surprised by how many more things this book made me think about while I was reading it. The book is divided into four parts, which I won’t go into great detail on, but rather just focus on a few of the most thought-provoking parts to me. The first section details the journey that mass-scale corn and beef make from the production plant to the table. Again, much of this was discussed in “King Corn,” but what Pollan does so well is connect the dots for people like me who never really saw the direct relationship between seemingly disparate facts. Case in point: I never knew that the rumens of cows technically can’t process corn. I feel stupid saying that, but hey, I’m a girl from San Diego who only ever saw a cow in real life if it was winning a prize at the Del Mar Fair. Because cows cannot naturally process corn (which they are fed because we produce it so prodigiously, and subsidize the price at the expense of the farmer, who can barely make a living), and because they live packed together, knee deep in manure, cows are fed a heavy diet of antibiotics. For the past ten years, the medical field has been dealing with increasing occurrences of drug-resistant infections – meaning that people have developed a resistance to life-saving drugs because they have been overexposed to or have misused antibiotics. It’s a subject I’m keenly interested in – in another life I might have been an epidemiologist – but I have to wonder if consumption of animals (chickens and pork too) that are heavily fed antibiotics is a contributing factor to this marked (and scary) increase. I never connected the two together before this book. Pollan also delves into the huge increase in food-borne illnesses and deaths since 1980. Again, those who know me know that I have had severe food poisoning three times, and I have had to be hospitalized the past two times. Those two hospitalizations came not from tainted beef or meat, but from spinach/lettuce. In fact, the last food poisoning (in January 2010) was so serious, and the bacteria so toxic, that if I had been living even 50 years earlier it would have killed me. But then again, if I had been living 50 years ago, there wouldn’t be a food industry system in place that would have made this sort of bacterial contamination happen. I came out of these experiences saying I would only eat organic lettuce from now on, and that I would think twice about ordering a salad when eating out unless it was organic. I kept my blinders on and didn’t really feel compelled to look further into where or what I eat. This book really changed all of that.Since I’ve already written a short novel, I will try to sum up things as best I can. Pollan’s chapter about organics on a large and small scale is fascinating and worth a read, as well as his sections on foraging and hunting. I came out of the book with a much deeper understanding of what I eat, and the costs associated with it. While the cost at the grocery checkout might be less for certain non-organic items, there is a far greater social cost behind that dollar amount for many mass-scale products. His basic motto: eat organic and grass fed when you can, as local and in season as possible. Support local farmers if you can. I’ve heard that said before, but it really makes sense now. I also realize that motto equates to a higher grocery bill, and I’ve made the decision that I will spend that extra amount when I have the choice between organic and non-organic. If it means I spend $25-$50 less on drinks or eating out each month in order to pay for the increased grocery bill, for example, so be it. But I also realize that not everyone can afford to make this same decision, and so does Pollan. He doesn’t preach or stuff things down your thought, which I really appreciated. He ‘gets’ it. He tries to offer reasonable solutions for the vast majority of people, and just wants to help shed light on lifestyle changes that could result in a healthier population. I’m leaving out a ton of other great information from the book, but all I can say is that it’s worth reading if you’re interested in your personal health, the economic and public health of your communities, and where your food comes from. ...more

title: The Windup Girl
author: Bacigalupi, Paolo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't typically describe books this way, but the best way to describe "The Wind-Up Girl" is deftly written. It took me about 100 pages to really getI don't typically describe books this way, but the best way to describe "The Wind-Up Girl" is deftly written. It took me about 100 pages to really get into the book, and during that time I was seriously considering if I had hit my limit on dystopic sci-fi portayals of the future. But I kept going, and I'm so glad I did. I realize now that Bacigalupi needs about 100 pages to establish the world he's created and the characters in it; once he's done that he interweaves their story lines and the plot extremely well, and it turned into a real page-turner. "The Wind-up Girl" makes you think about the implications of genetically modified foods, environmental degradation, technological advances, etc, and creates a world in which some of the ideas being floated around today have come to fruition -- for better or worse. The premise is interesting, but Bacigalupi manages to make the people who occupy this world even more compelling. It's safe to say that many of the characters are not particularly likable, but they are (here's that word again) deftly painted in grey. As a reader you feel conflicted about how you should feel when things do or don't work out for these characters. No one person is clearly a villain...they all, for the most part, lie in the grey. Emiko, the wind-up girl of the title, is the only wholly sympathetic character -- one who evolves to become an example of the 'kick-ass' female protaganists that are making a resurgence right now in fiction. She's a great character, and one that I could see Bacigalupi continuing in a series. ...more

review: One of this past month’s book club picks. From the minute you read the first page of this novel, you know you are in good hands. Ishiguro makes the voOne of this past month’s book club picks. From the minute you read the first page of this novel, you know you are in good hands. Ishiguro makes the voice of the protagonist, Stevens the butler, so clearly defined, and you can immediately imagine him as a character – as a real, live person, actually. You can see him and his every mannerisms fully formed, as you can the other characters in the novel. I don’t often put much weight in the pulled quotes on the front and back of a book, but on my book there was a quote from Salman Rushdie, who called it “a story both beautiful and cruel.” I think that’s the most succinct description I can give for it. It slowly devastates you, as Stevens reflects on his life and on the ‘fine, dignified men’ which he served. I don’t want to give away much of the story, so I’ll leave it at that. review: Just nowhere near as compelling as the first novel. People have been asking me about the book for a while, because the story revolves around an exposeJust nowhere near as compelling as the first novel. People have been asking me about the book for a while, because the story revolves around an expose of the human trafficking industry (and I used to work in the Anti-Human Trafficking Unit of the UN Office on Drugs and Crime); Larsson gets the facts mostly straight, with a few embellishments. For the most part, people who deal in human trafficking deal in trafficking drugs and/or firearms as well, and that is the bulk of their business. It's less expensive and often less risky to traffick drugs or firearms (unlike people, they don't need to be fed, housed, etc. They also don't talk.). Larsson made it sound like it was the other way around -- sex trafficking was the primary revenue source, and drugs later. But this is a very academic sort of analysis of a pop culture thriller. It took me a while to get into this book, and I felt like I knew how it was going to play out after 100 pages. I like the characters, so I keep reading the book, but it just couldn't hold a candle to the first book....more

title: The Bridge of San Luis Rey
author: Wilder, Thornton
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Great art -- whether written, performed, painted, etc – stirs your soul and makes you reflect on your life and on the world around you. This book is gGreat art -- whether written, performed, painted, etc – stirs your soul and makes you reflect on your life and on the world around you. This book is great art. In just 108 pages, Wilder creates a beautiful story, complete with interesting, complex characters, and a premise that is as timeless and relevant now as when it was written (and when it takes place). On an ordinary day in Peru in the 1700s, a legendary bridge collapses, and five people fall to their death. A Catholic priest decides to look into their lives and see if they were virtuous or sinners, to try and get an explanation for why God allowed this to happen. Like all of us, each one of the victims was a nuanced and complicated person who didn’t fit neatly and cleanly into one category. Each one had felt pain and given others pain. The story and its message is fantastic and thought-provoking, but I have to also say that the prose is beautiful. There were no less than five occasions in which I read a sentence and was stopped in my tracks, struck by its beauty and its truth. And even the minor characters were memorable and well formed. I found myself thinking about this book long after I put it down....more

title: The Magicians        (The Magicians, #1)
author: Grossman, Lev*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s a tricky thing, setting up the plot of your book so that you will inevitably be compared to the greats in the genre. But that’s what Grossman doeIt’s a tricky thing, setting up the plot of your book so that you will inevitably be compared to the greats in the genre. But that’s what Grossman does with The Magicians, which liberally borrows from the Narnia tales and even a bit from Harry Potter. Unfortunately, for me, the comparison was to Grossman’s disadvantage. The premise of the book is great – a smart, awkward teenager (right out of the semi-nerd mold) who is obsessed with childhood fantasy books about Fillory (e.g. Narnia) gets recruited to attend a secret magical university, and in the last portion of the book, actually goes to Fillory. But the premise never really fulfilled its promise for me. Grossman seems to want to make the point that doing magic is tedious, difficult, and not really ‘magical’ at all – it’s sort of like doing a calculus problem set. But in repeatedly stressing this point, he takes the, well, magic, out of the story. The pacing was often slow, the character development could have been stronger, and to be honest, the only characters I had the slightest bit of emotional engagement with were Alice and Eliot (and Eliot only because it seemed like he might have an interesting backstory…which you never learn). Grossman wrote this to be at least a two-part series (the sequel is out now), but I just don’t have any interest in continuing the story with him. I didn’t get the hype. I guess I just prefer my fantasy stories to have more literary ‘magic’ in them....more

title: A Happy Marriage
author: Yglesias, Rafael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a hard book to . It’s not the sort of book I’m typically drawn to, but I heard the novelist interviewed on NPR and my interest was piqueThis is a hard book to . It’s not the sort of book I’m typically drawn to, but I heard the novelist interviewed on NPR and my interest was piqued. It’s a fictionalized version of the author’s own life and 30-year marriage with his wife Margaret, who passed away from cancer in 2004. It’s billed as a ‘warts and all’ look at a marriage, and Iglesias has the story jump back and forth from when he first met his wife at age 21, to her last weeks as she dies from cancer. It sort of meets in the middle of their life, which even includes his one-year affair with one of his wife’s friends while their first son was young. I guess part of the challenge is that I feel like I’m ing someone’s life, not a novel. I’m in no place to judge someone else’s marriage. As a novel, I found the places that I felt like I wanted more was actually around the affair and its aftermath. Ultimately he decides to stay with his wife because he feels it’s the right thing to do for his son. And over the course of the book you see how deeply he falls in love with his wife once again, but he details little of what made him fall back in love with his wife. He also makes a point of saying that he never told his wife about the affair before she passed – he meant to, but never had the right moment. You wonder if he did her a kindness or not. I thought the two of them were very real people, who even though they lived a life of privilege had the same quirks, flaws, and beautiful qualities that so many of us have. And ultimately the novel is about the fact that he was a man who spent his whole life trying to build a name for himself as a novelist, but the best thing he ever created in his life was his marriage and his two sons – they were the real purpose and accomplishments of his life, and the best thing he will leave behind. Not his career. And I think that’s a theme that resonates with a lot of us. I don’t feel like you need to be married to appreciate this novel – in essence it is a novel about the relationships (romantic, platonic, or familial) that define your life. And it shows how God forsakenly awful cancer is. ...more

review: I don’t want to give any spoilers away, so it’s a little hard for me to make specific criticisms about this book. First, on the whole, I loved the triI don’t want to give any spoilers away, so it’s a little hard for me to make specific criticisms about this book. First, on the whole, I loved the trilogy but I don’t think they are young adult (YA). I think the subject matter and the graphicness of them are not YA, and the only reason that they were classified as YA is because it gives Collins license to use the same plot devices in all three books. Again, I won’t get into specifics, but there is one plot element that is amazing in the first novel; when it appeared again in the second novel I thought “Huh. Well, ok, I guess she found a way to bring it back again.” When it happened in the third novel, I almost got angry. It felt lazy to me, but in a YA book it’s more acceptable. But these books are for adults – I’m not being provincial here. They really are. And in the last 100 pages of the book I got really frustrated. Collins tries to now overtly make the point that the series has been all about the effects of war on children, but in ways she glamorized some of the components of war, but later keeps saying “But wait, it’s bad.” Her whole message got muddled. All of this being said, I flew through the trilogy and really, really enjoyed it. I realize I’m holding her up to a high standard. But just like a teacher expects a certain level of work from a highly proficient student (unfairly, perhaps), I thought the final book was a B-level effort. ...more

title: My Booky Wook
author: Brand, Russell
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve never read a celebrity autobiography before, and I’m not entirely sure what possessed me to pick Russell Brand as my first. Actually, I do know. I’ve never read a celebrity autobiography before, and I’m not entirely sure what possessed me to pick Russell Brand as my first. Actually, I do know. It was a  of it I read in the NYT a while back that was uncharacteristically positive, and when I started seeing all these ps for Russell Brand movies lately I decided to pick it up from the library on a lark.Putting aside the fact that very few people should be writing autobiographies about themselves when they are only 30, on the whole it’s a so-so book. The book’s subtitle says that is a memoir of sex, drugs, and stand-up. By my count, it was mainly 5% standup, 20% sex addiction (and this is not sexy reading – it merely states that he slept with a bevy of women at this place and that place, etc), and 75% drug addiction. The drug addiction fueled the sex addiction, and the reason so little of the stand-up is covered is because Brand was so wasted while doing stand-up that he can’t really remember much of what happened. He seems like a lot of intelligent, gifted comedians who have a dark side that has been self-medicated through life with alcohol, drugs, etc. I guess that Brand should be given credit for writing such an honest assessment of himself – in short he recounts just how much of a jerk he was for most of his life to everyone in his life, because of his numerous addictions. But I almost think he did too good of a job – he just kept coming off as a jerk, and he became decreasingly likable. By the end of the book (2006, I think) he seems to have redeemed himself, and having cleaned himself he is just about to branch out into international stardom (“Forgetting Sarah Marshall,” “Get to the Him to the Greek,” etc).My other issue with the book is that the areas that I found to be the most interesting – how he got clean, his true low points as an addict, how he makes amends to the ones he loves – are sort of breezed through and skimmed over in the last chapter of the book. Maybe the average reader is more interested in the outrageous antics and over-the-top stuff that happened when Brand was high, but I thought the parts with the real humanity in there were far more interesting – and too few and far between. The other thing, which isn’t his fault, is that he continually references British pop culture and British actors that I’ve never heard of – it probably would be a lot more enjoyable a read if I knew who these people were and had a knowledge of the events to which he was referring. Not a criticism of him, really, but it did affect how much I enjoyed the book. I caught a little bit of Brand on TV on Friday, when he was co-hosting “Regis and Kelly” with Kelly Ripa. He was intelligent, very quick and witty, and exactly how I’ve enjoyed seeing him before. I sort of want to forget this book and only think of him as that very funny, very gifted comedian. Sometimes it’s better to not know the darker side of someone. ...more

review: In hindsight, reading “The Road” immediately after the Japan earthquake, and during two solid weeks of rain, probably wasn’t a good idea. It definitelIn hindsight, reading “The Road” immediately after the Japan earthquake, and during two solid weeks of rain, probably wasn’t a good idea. It definitely got to me. There was one moment in the book – a small moment, one that no one else would probably even remember – that really got to my head. The father has a flashback of the moments after the apocalyptic event occurs. The father immediately goes into the bathroom and starts filling the bathtub up with water. His wife asks him why he is taking a bath, and he tells her he isn’t. It’s a tiny moment that hit me hard because immediately filling up your bathtub with water is something they teach you to do after a big earthquake – you do it so that you have clean, potable water to drink in case the water pipes burst, get contaminated, or just shut off. It’s the sort of thing you do to have control over an uncontrollable situation, and to make you feel like you’re going to get through this event and be just fine. It’s a flashback from many years before, and you see where his life has gone since then, and what he has suffered and lost since that moment. I thought the story was beautiful, and whereas I didn’t care for McCarthy’s sparse prose in “All the Pretty Horses,” his writing style made sense in this post-apocalyptic story. There were moments between the father and son that just ripped my heart out. Someone asked me why I would want to read a book that is so bleak and depressing, and it’s hard to describe, because while I wouldn’t call it a happy book, it’s a tremendously moving one, and in a way, the ending is about the happiest you’re going to get from Cormac McCarthy. There are many lessons and messages to take away from the story – the unwavering, relentless love between a father and son, the primal savageness that lurks just underneath our surface – but above all I think that McCarthy’s created a book that is a metaphor for life. Faced with even insurmountable circumstances, and no hope on the horizon, you have to keep going and keep moving, and always be “one of the good guys.” To be complacent in your life and stop moving and changing will lead to disaster. And be grateful for every day and every minute that you have with the ones you love. ...more

While going door to door Samuel discovers that one of his neighbors is trying to open up the Gates of Hell, and is actually successful. Demons, ghouls, and mayhem ensues, with Samuel trying to get adults to listen to him and help him save the day. It has a fair amount of background in physics in the book, and I actually felt like I learned some things from it! title: Let the Great World Spin
author: McCann, Colum*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My dear friend Russell places this book in his Top 50 books of all time (this is an example of one of the many reasons why I love Russell -- he doesn'My dear friend Russell places this book in his Top 50 books of all time (this is an example of one of the many reasons why I love Russell -- he doesn't have a Top 5 or Top 10 book list, he has a Top 50!), and I think I would have to do the same. It's a beautifully written book that highlights the lives of a dozen or so characters whose stories are interrelated and interwoven with one another around one single event -- Philippe Petit's historic tightrope walk between the Twin Towers in 1974. But the book is only minimally about the tightroping event itself, and more about the people whose lives are changed, directly or indirectly, on that day. Each character was distinct and fully formed, and while there were a couple of characters whose stories I might have omitted (only because I didn't feel like their inclusion really added much to the story), on the whole it is wonderful. Moving, heartfelt, and ambitious in its scope. I had one tiny little quibble with the book -- that the character Claire was supposed to have gone to Yale in the 1950s, but women weren't admitted to Yale College until 1968. It's a small thing, but there are enough Yalies in the publishing world that someone should have caught that at some point along the way. :)We unexpectedly had a death in the family, and I found myself reading and finishing this book while in New York, which I certainly hadn't anticipated. It added a deeper resonance to the book, being back in New York for a memorial, and at the same time driving past the former World Trade Center site. Even if you haven't been to New York or you don't have a strong connection to the city, I would recommend it. Ultimately it's about the connections between all of us -- flawed, vulnerable human beings -- and the visions we have for our lives and ourselves....more

title: Assassination Vacation
author: Vowell, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sarah Vowell is a contributing editor of NPR’s “This American Life,” and she’s always witty and often laugh-out-loud funny. Like the sort of book thatSarah Vowell is a contributing editor of NPR’s “This American Life,” and she’s always witty and often laugh-out-loud funny. Like the sort of book that makes people on the bus look at you because they can’t understand why you would be laughing while reading a book. I’ll be the first to admit that Vowell’s nerdy and slightly macabre style and wit are right up my alley (a humor book about taking vacations to the various sites around the US dedicated to the assassinations of Presidents Lincoln, Garfield, and McKinley? Sign me up!). Like her, I can’t walk past a plaque on a building and not feel compelled to read it. I like the feeling of knowing that something significant happened right where I am standing, and trying to envision that place and moment when it happened. And Vowell does a great job of mixing history with funny anecdotes about the journey of exploring these various places, making someone with only a small amount of interest in presidential assassinations find the book to be fascinating, funny, and gosh darn it, educational, too!The other strength of Vowell’s writing is the warmth she exudes when talking about the people she meets, this nation, and about her own family. One sentence that really struck me was about her two-week “assassination vacation” trip with her twin sister Amy and Amy’s three year-old son Owen. The fact that her sister agreed to be the driver/chauffeur for this bizarre trip (with her three year-old in tow) speaks volumes about how much she loves her sister Sarah, and their interactions also reflect the love that you can have for your siblings and family – you want to be a part of something just because you know how happy it makes them. And one of my favorite lines goes something like this: “While I am never surprised by how much I love my nephew Owen, I am continue to be pleasantly surprised by how much I like him.” Which is to say that you will always love your family, but when you find that even if you weren’t related to someone you’d still like them anyway, that’s saying something. Along these lines, when Vowell meets the colorful cast of characters who run these historic monuments, off-the-beaten path pilgrimage sites, etc, she portrays them with a humanity and warmth that a lesser writer couldn’t do, because they would be tempted to make fun of them. It’s a quick read (250 pages, large-ish font), and if you have any interest in history, or just like the humorists on “This American Life,” I’d highly recommend “Assassination Vacation.”...more

title: Palace of Desire
author: Mahfouz, Naguib
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really, really want to love these books. I really do. For Pete’s sake, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis was instrumental in getting them translated into EI really, really want to love these books. I really do. For Pete’s sake, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis was instrumental in getting them translated into English, and you know how I love Jackie O! But I find that I can’t get into them as much as I would like. This book picks up with Al-Hamzawi five years after the end of the first book, and the characters are dealing with the passage of time and the loss of one of the young family members. In this book I found the mother Amina to be a far more compelling character, the image of a woman who has been subservient her entire life, but now that she has had to bury one of her children far too soon, she can no longer keep her emotions in check. She yells, she gets angry, she cries – in short, she gets a backbone. It’s refreshing, because the women in Mahfouz’s books continue to be the most sympathetic characters for me. The book took a strange telenovela-inspired turn when it comes to the sexual relationships and affairs of the men in the family. The father, getting older, begins to lust after the young lute player Zanuba, the niece of Zabayda, one of his long-time mistresses. He doesn’t know that Zanuba used to be sleeping with his son Yasin, and when Zanuba sees that she can be a ‘kept woman’ with the father she doesn’t exactly offer up this information, either. The son Yasin, for his part, lusts after the woman whom his late brother Fahmy was in love with, Maryam, and resigns himself to marrying her when he realizes that this is the only way he will bed her. And then he proceeds to have an affair with Zanuba the lute player – that’s right, the same one who is sleeping with his father. Zanuba ultimately splits with the father, and Yasin divorces Maryam and marries Zanuba. Yasin never knows that his wife use to sleep with his father, but the father obviously knows the secret when his son secretly weds Zanuba. Still following me? It’s basically one incestuous pool of infidelity, which is completely at odds with the pious life of Islam to which the men say they ascribe. And it continues the dichotomy of woman as saint and woman as whore.The most refreshing part of this book is that the child Kamil of book 1 is now an 18-year old man in “Palace Walk,” and he shows in heartwrenching detail what it feels like to have your heart broken for the very first time. It is actually his story line in “Palace Walk” that will make me continue to finish the trilogy. I feel like I can admire Mahfouz from a technical perspective, because he is a good writer (like Dickens), but the books just feel a bit ponderous. ...more

It's the most popular (and controversial) modern novel in the Arab world, and it highlights the lives of a dozen residents of a Cairo building. While it reads a bit like a soap opera, it does a fantastic job of showing modern Cairo in all its beauty and contradictions. The author had a dental practice in the real Yacoubian building, and apparently the stories are fairly autobiographical. It's a quick read, and great if you want to know more about modern Egypt and all of the undercurrents that are playing out in the news today....more

review: As I read these three novellas, I started thinking about how sometimes in an art museum you see a work of art, and while you can admire that it is tecAs I read these three novellas, I started thinking about how sometimes in an art museum you see a work of art, and while you can admire that it is technically proficient and the artist is exceptionally skilled, it doesn't 'sing' to you. And then you turn the corner and one piece just jumps out at you, knocks you off your feet, and you think, "God, I feel like my life has been changed just by being in the presence of this art." This is how I felt about Auster's three novellas. The first two, "City of Glass," and "Ghosts," I found clever but not altogether satisfying. The third and final novella, "The Glass Room," is arguably the best novella I have ever read, and strangely, I realized that in order for me to fully appreciate the genius of it, I had to read the two stories that preceded it...which on their own I didn't exactly love. Auster's mind-bending, psychological examination of language and the entire detective genre is fantastic, and I'm still haunted by "The Locked Room." ...more

review: Our latest book club pick, “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” is definitely the sort of novel I would have liked reading with a class. I enjoyed the magOur latest book club pick, “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” is definitely the sort of novel I would have liked reading with a class. I enjoyed the magical realism employed throughout, and there are moments of pure poetry in the book. In fact, the very first line of the book might be my favorite opening line to a book, EVER. (Quick aside: Marquez’s first line rivals Ernest Hemingway’s famed “shortest story,” which was created when members of the Algonquin Round Table made a bet that no one could write a complete story with a beginning, middle, and end in six words or less. Hemingway scribbled on the back of a cocktail napkin: “For sale. Baby shoes. Never worn.” Each member of the Round Table proceeded to cough up $10 to Hemingway, knowing he had achieved what none of them could.)I alternated between really loving this book and feeling like it dragged – in those parts in particular I think I would have benefitted from having a discussion group with whom I could have dissected things. I often felt like I wasn’t reading it with the depth it really deserves. I could definitely see how Marquez has influenced so many writers with his use of magical realism, and he really does it best. But I’m hoping that our book club meeting will help me delve into the book a bit deeper....more

author: Mahfouz, Naguib
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While preparing for our trip to Egypt, I realized that my knowledge of Egypt was embarrassingly relegated to what happened there thousands of years agWhile preparing for our trip to Egypt, I realized that my knowledge of Egypt was embarrassingly relegated to what happened there thousands of years ago. I could barely remember any of the little history I learned about Egypt in the past thousand years or so. So I borrowed Mahfouz’s “Cairo Trilogy,” which won the Nobel Prize, in the hopes of informing my knowledge of more modern Egypt. I’m not going to lie. This wasn’t an easy book for me. In the best and worst sense, it reminds me of Dickens – beautifully written, intelligent, and often very, very slow. It also pushed my own culturally relative limits. At times, I couldn’t tell if the author though that the treatment towards the female protagonists was appropriate or abusive, and tried as I might to be non-judgmental, I thought the relationships toward many of the women were abusive. And they highlighted the eternal struggle of woman as saint or whore. A man wants his wife to be virginal and pure, the saintly mother of his children, following all of God’s credos, but the man must also have women on the side with whom he has multiple affairs, breaking numerous laws in the Koran while he goes home and throws out his wife for leaving the house for the first time EVER in 20+ years, only because she wanted to pray at the mosque. It was frustrating and challenging to read, but if anything, the fact that it got me so riled up shows how much I started to get wrapped up in these characters. Up until the last 50 pages, I thought I wouldn’t go through with finishing the Trilogy. But enough happened in those last pages for me to think that I’ll continue with books 2 and 3 before heading to Egypt. ...more

review: So I decided to lead a book club for opera donors at my work, where we read the literary text behind an upcoming opera. This was the first selection oSo I decided to lead a book club for opera donors at my work, where we read the literary text behind an upcoming opera. This was the first selection of the book club. Reading my Dad's copy of the book that he bought in college, it was a bit strange to see what points he highlighted and focused on 40+ years ago (in fact, he has no recollection of even reading the book). I can appreciate this book for its role in the development of literature, and I enjoy it much more as a psychological study of the most truly Romantic figures in literature. It's a story well-suited to opera, and I enjoyed the discussion it provoked at the book club. I found Werther's manner of rationalizing the acceptance of suicide in God's eyes to be one of the more interesting theories I've heard, and I imagine it was fairly radical for the time. I'm not sure how many people would have interest in reading it if they aren't opera fans or 18th century German Romantic literature fans, but it was perfectly enjoyable. ...more

review: Not since "Corelli's Mandolin" have I had such a strong desire to throw a book against a wall upon finishing it. (Note: This  contains spoilers)Not since "Corelli's Mandolin" have I had such a strong desire to throw a book against a wall upon finishing it. (Note: This  contains spoilers). And I really, really wanted to like "Portrait of a Lady." In fact, when reading the first 100 pages I thought this could be a book I could love. But after 200, 300, 400, 500 pages of reading and very little happening, I got increasingly frustrated with it. I know I'm supposed to take away a lot from this book about the empowerment of women, the role of money in one's happiness, etc, but it all felt hollow to me. And I didn't get WHY everyone loves Isabel Archer. James makes a point of telling you that she's beautiful and she's charming, but she damn well didn't show it to me. I just didn't care about her, and I didn't entirely understand why she saw nothing in Lord Warburton. Honestly, the girl must be crazy. And then, when I've clearly figured out that Isabel isn't going to be leaving her husband, and she goes to visit Pansy in the convent, and I think to myself, "Ok, good. Isabel can't really escape the life she made for herself, but she can liberate Pansy, and give Pansy the freedom to be with Rosier." BUT SHE LEAVES PANSY AT THE CONVENT, to suffer in her life the way she suffers in her. It's infuriating! I'm sure there are far deeper reasons as to why she does it, but I just didn't get it. And ultimately, I guess I didn't get the point of the entire 610 pages, either. ...more

I will say that the thing that struck me most about the books (and isn’t really a critique of the books, but rather, the TV show) is that “True Blood” creator Alan Ball did a damn fine job of casting people based on their descriptions in the book. Sure, Tara wasn’t even in this book, and apparently when she does appear she isn’t black, but who cares? I was struck by how even minor characters in the books were brought to the screen almost verbatim from the book. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was our latest book club pick, and it was selected because many in the literary community think that Alice Munro should win the Pulitzer Prize; iThis was our latest book club pick, and it was selected because many in the literary community think that Alice Munro should win the Pulitzer Prize; it’s reputed that the only reason she hasn’t is that no author who exclusively writes short stories has ever won (oh, literary politics). Munro’s writing style is clean, even sparse at times, but she has an ability to pack a mean emotional punch. I’ve heard it said that her stories illuminate the extraordinary in the ordinary lives of people, and it’s a fair depiction of her style. The stories in this collection range in era from the 1930s to the 1970s, and they primarily focus on the lives of rural or isolated people in Canada. I must say that throughout the earlier stories, the phrase “leading lives of quiet desperation” constantly came to mind. So did the music of Neko Case, for that matter (“Fox Confessor Brings the Flood” would be the perfect audio barbiturate for a reading session). One thing that sets Munro apart for me is her decision to write several short stories about the same protagonist. Each story highlights the character at different points in her life – almost as if an omniscient being were to look in on a selection of moments in your life (sort of like Rip Torn in “Defending Your Life”). You saw the emotional points the character was at – age 20 and in college, divorced at 43, etc. It made it easier to stay engrossed in the collection, because you really felt like you were starting to get under the skin of a character.There is a distinctly melancholy feel to Munro’s stories – not tragic, but many of the characters were dealing with unhappy points in their life and trying to work their way through them. Whether it was the humiliation of a parent in front of their children in Depression-era Ontario, or dealing with loneliness after a one-night stand that the protagonist hadn’t thought would be a one-night stand, the mood was a somber, reflective, a little sad. title: Mansfield Park
author: Austen, Jane
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** "Mansfield Park" has been called Austen’s “most profound and perplexing novel,” and it truly is perplexing. Part of Austen’s appeal **spoiler alert** "Mansfield Park" has been called Austen’s “most profound and perplexing novel,” and it truly is perplexing. Part of Austen’s appeal to me has always been that she created strong, intelligent female characters who, within the confines of their families and social structures, assert themselves and demonstrate that they have a mind and presence all their own. And then Fanny Price comes along. As protagonist of “Mansfield Park,” she is the anti-Austen heroine. Fanny is the epitome of a wet blanket – weak, timid, with no confidence in herself, and really no personality to speak of. Plucked from her family at the age of 10 and brought to live with her affluent aunt, uncle, and cousins, she is a woman with no clear sense of family and where she belongs, and this certainly does inform her personality. She is thought to be beneath her wealthy cousins, but she no longer fits in with her less advantaged biological family, who just don’t know what to do with her. It may be that because she does not have a strong family model in which to operate, and because she is in many ways rootless, that she cannot be like the other Austen heroines. And that may have been Austen’s point. But the resulting character, and subsequently the novel, creates a world in which you have little emotional investment in the story and its inhabitants. How I wished to have the swelling of heart that I felt when Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Bennet finally unite, or when Eleanor realizes that Mr. Robert Ferrars has been married to Lucy, not the Mr. Edward Ferrars of her heart! But instead, after a 400-page slog through “Mansfield Park,” I learn two pages before the end of the novel that at some point in the future (spoiler alert here) Fanny marries her cousin Edmund, who is basically the only man who has ever been genuinely nice to her. Eww factor aside, the simple fact that Edward has clearly loved Fanny “as a sister” throughout the novel, and in no place do I see where his love moves from filial to romantic, makes the ending completely unsatisfyingPerhaps I am reading too much into it, but “Mansfield Park” strikes me with a bit of bitterness on Austen’s part. As one of her last novels, which she wrote as an older unwed woman, it almost feels like her image of love has changed, and she wonders just how many marriages can be truly based on love. The patched-on nature of the conclusion of “Mansfield Park” seems to suggest this, and her own satire on religion and morality also seem to suggest that she no longer possesses the bright-eyed optimism of her youth. I think I’ll stick with her earlier novels from now on. ...more

The thing that kept popping up in my mind as I read the book was a statistic from an essay of David Foster Wallace’s that I read earlier this year. The essay said that in the adult film industry, something like 70% of all adult films show women being abused (often violently) and/or put in some role of submission and subservience. I was shocked when I read the statistic (I guess showing my limited knowledge of the vast world of adult film), and I thought of it every time Lisbeth said, “Just another man who hates women,” or Larson mentioned another statistic about sexual violence against women in Sweden. title: Street Gang: The Complete History of Sesame Street
author: Davis, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** Overall a good read, and a thorough analysis of how “Sesame Street” came to be. My main criticism of the book was that I felt it del**spoiler alert** Overall a good read, and a thorough analysis of how “Sesame Street” came to be. My main criticism of the book was that I felt it delved too much into the overall history of children’s television, and it went into the back history of every single person who ever had any role in the show. It’s wonderful that these individuals finally get more recognition for the roles they played, but I felt like the result was that it covered very little ground on the two individuals I was most interested in: Jim Henson and Frank Oz. Maybe Davis thinks that enough books have been written about these two puppeteers that he should cover the other folks, but come on, how do you have a book about the history of “Sesame Street” and cover so little about the two of them? I wanted backstage stories about how certain characters evolved, funny outtakes, the works. I guess the flip side of that is that I didn’t learn anything about Jim Henson that really upset me or changed my opinion of him, which can be the dangerous thing about biographies of people you like (e.g. “White Christmas” just never felt as moving to me after I found out that Bing Crosby was an alcoholic wife beater).The book is more somber than you might expect, and I came away from it with three lessons:1)	Harvard and Yale really do run the world. I knew it working at Yale, but honestly, the doors that get opened and the connections that get made in the Ivy League really do change things. And “Sesame Street,” at the Executive and writing levels, was populated almost exclusively with Ivy Leaguers. 2)	You can’t have your cake and eat it too. The moral of the “Sesame Street” story is that the majority of these folks spent their lives working on this amazing, groundbreaking show that changed children’s education – but often at the expense of their marriage and/or raising their children. People who might have wanted children never had the opportunity to do so because they worked all the time; people who did have children never saw them because, ironically, they were busy creating children’s educational programming for the world’s children; and often you could be married to “Sesame Street” or to your spouse, but you couldn’t do both. 3)	It appears that working on “Sesame Street” took an enormous physical toll on its staff, and an inordinate amount of them died very young (under the age of 65). The last two chapters are basically a eulogy for the majority of the show’s core team, who all died prematurely of cancer, ALS, AIDS, depression, cardiac arrest, and pneumonia. ...more

title: Anna Karenina
author: Tolstoy, Leo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I almost don’t know where to begin with “Anna Karenina.” Like Rushdie’s “Midnight’s Children,” Tolstoy manages to create an entire universe in AK thatI almost don’t know where to begin with “Anna Karenina.” Like Rushdie’s “Midnight’s Children,” Tolstoy manages to create an entire universe in AK that can’t be encapsulated in a Goodreads post. I knew so little about the novel before picking it up -- basically all I knew was that it didn’t exactly end well for Anna. But in many ways I felt the most compelling parts of AK were not at all about her; rather, the storyline of the Levins felt far more authentic and real to me. To be sure, Tolstoy writes Anna with a great deal more sympathy than most male authors of his period would have. But I felt that his description of the love affair between Anna and Vronsky was one of the weakest points of the novel – apart from the fact that she’s beautiful, and he’s beautiful, I didn’t see what drew them to each other, and beyond that what really kept them together. In stark contrast to that was the love affair between Kitty and Levin, which felt genuine and alive – when they fell in love, I knew why.For me, Tolstoy’s greatest achievements were in the little vignettes about the relationships and moments that define our lives: the courtship and confession of love between Kitty and Levin, Anna’s visiting of her son on his birthday, Levin’s anxieties about his pregnant wife and their unborn child, and even Alexey Alexandrovitch’s behavior when confronted with the fact that his wife no longer loves him. Tolstoy is masterful at creating shades of grey, and showing characters at their best, at their worst, and how most of us, most of the time, fall somewhere in between. Even if I didn’t agree with a character’s actions, I often understood their position and why they acted the way they did. That a book published 140 years ago still feels timely and relevant today is a testament to Tolstoy.Sure, the fact that every character seemed to blush or flush at the slightest thing felt Victorian and a bit dated. The wild flashes of jealousy that seem to possess each character at one point or another feel, a little, well, Russian. And by the end Anna was starting to annoy me so much that I was beginning to look forward to her tragic end. But I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this book, and how a novel that was 900 pages long didn’t feel as laborious as I expected. ...more

review: I’ll never quite understand what makes a book be classified as Young Adult (or “YA”). Like Philip Pullman’s “His Dark Materials” trilogy, I’m sort of I’ll never quite understand what makes a book be classified as Young Adult (or “YA”). Like Philip Pullman’s “His Dark Materials” trilogy, I’m sort of shocked that “The Book Thief” is considered YA. Perhaps the marketing folks at publishing houses think that if the protagonist of a novel is a child or teen, it naturally fits best in the YA category. In the case of the beautiful, haunting “Book Thief,” I’m afraid that a whole segment of readers will miss this book because it won’t be easy to find in their library or bookstore.Narrated by Death (whom, depending on your spiritual beliefs, could be seen as an angel, a scythe-wielding reaper, or any other sort of manifestation), the novel follows a girl named Liesl, raised by foster parents in Germany during the rise of the Nazi Party and the onset of WWII. It’s well-tread subject matter, but what makes “The Book Thief” stand apart is the clear, clever, and impactful prose of the writer, Marcus Zusak. review: I’m not entirely sure why, but all my life I’ve been drawn to stories that take place in the Holocaust. I even took a class on Dutch Literature of theI’m not entirely sure why, but all my life I’ve been drawn to stories that take place in the Holocaust. I even took a class on Dutch Literature of the Holocaust in college “just for fun,” which I guess can be classified as both nerdy and a bit morbid. And then I married someone whose maternal grandparents were Holocaust survivors (not intentionally, obviously). I sometimes wonder if there are just certain themes and subjects that the universe has decided are going to play a part in your life, and for me, the Holocaust and World War II seem to play a recurring role. I can’t explain why, particularly when I grew up a Catholic in San Diego, and my German great-grandparents emigrated to the States before the first World War, but I guess that’s why you leave things up to a higher power.“City of Thieves” is a good story about World War II, made very good by the fact that the story is based on the lives of the author’s maternal grandparents. Without it being based on someone’s real life, the story would fall flat for me, and it would feel like it’s trying too hard to hit the most extreme range of emotions. Benioff is a screenwriter by trade (something I did not know before I started the book), and the novel does seem to read like a movie at times…not quite like a screenplay, but you can easily see it being made into a movie (which Benioff is probably hoping for). You sort of feel like movie studio executives are secretly the target audience, but at the end of the day the book is so darn compelling and such a quick, entertaining read that I couldn’t help but enjoy it. ...more

title: Consider the Lobster and Other Essays
author: Wallace, David Foster
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s hard not to read this book without the knowledge of Wallace’s tragic suicide informing your impressions of the book. Call it morbid curiosity, buIt’s hard not to read this book without the knowledge of Wallace’s tragic suicide informing your impressions of the book. Call it morbid curiosity, but you find yourself unconsciously reading passages differently than you would if he were still alive. For example, in his analysis of Doestoevsky, he refers to “the unbelievably repellant Smerdyakov, that living engine of slimy resentment in whom I personally see parts of myself I can barely stand to look at.” It’s a passage you wouldn’t think twice about if read while the author is still living, but reading it after his depression-related suicide brings an unexpected sadness to an essay that is not meant to be sad (it is in fact a celebration of Doestoevsky, and because of the essay I’m willing to give Doestoevsky another go).Wallace is an immensely talented writer, and clearly a genius -- not a term I use often or throw around lightly. He is one of the most erudite writers I’ve ever read, and yet he still manages to keep the reader engaged, even when the subject is something as dry as an 80-page essay on the politics of the Dictionary of Modern English Usage. It won’t appeal to everyone (admittedly, its targeted demographic are those most ardent supporters of NPR’s "A Way With Words"), and he will challenge you as a reader (more on that to come), but I feel like a better reader for it. Wallace’s style is frenetic and tangential, often employing many, many footnotes, or the flat-out scattering of boxed “asides” all over the page. It can be frustrating because it makes the reading experience feel scattered, but I think that is his intended purpose (if you’ll indulge me for a Wallace-esque aside, Wallace reminds me of that kid you knew growing up who was SO smart, awkwardly smart, maybe even too smart for his own good. That kid for me was Hubert W., who ended up going to Cal with me and about four other classmates, and I never once saw him on campus in my whole four years there. Hubert today is either working on the cure for cancer or planning the destruction of us all – there really isn’t anything in between). Truthfully, one could easily do a full critique on each of the essays in this collection. His shortest essay, about experiencing 9/11 while in Bloomington, IN, was to me the most impactful of all his writings. It could have been the noticeable absence of his beloved footnotes, or the subject matter, but it was truthful and earnest in a way you don’t come to expect from someone like Wallace. I was also struck by the fact that Wallace was a church-going man of faith – again, not something you necessarily expect from a sardonic, left-leaning novelist/journalist in the 21st century. It was oddly refreshing. His essay following John McCain on the 2000 campaign trail is another gem, and the others are all interesting, albeit sometimes long (Wallace did need an editor). It’s enough to make me seriously consider undertaking his tome and masterpiece, "Infinite Jest." Stay tuned. ...more

title: Rabbit, Run        (Rabbit Angstrom, #1)
author: Updike, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The latest installment in our “Time Magazine/ Modern Library Top 100 Books of All Time” book club strategy. I literally knew nothing about the book, aThe latest installment in our “Time Magazine/ Modern Library Top 100 Books of All Time” book club strategy. I literally knew nothing about the book, and I secretly hoped for the anthropomorphizing of some small woodland creatures ala “Watership Down.” Alas, “Rabbit Run” is about a man named Harry, nicknamed “Rabbit” for his pale skin and twitchy demeanor. I went on such an emotional rollercoaster with this book, alternating between moments of passionate hate for the protagonist, and then my heart literally aching for the characters. Make no mistake, to my mind Rabbit is an arrogant, conceited, self-absorbed, misogynistic pig. I haven’t been so passionately antagonistic towards a character in recent memory. But he is still human, and there are moments in which I felt genuine sympathy for him. It struck me somewhere along the way that if I was getting this riled up about a character, borderline hating him, and then in turns feel such strong emotion toward the other characters, it had to be good. The turning point of the novel, read on my commute into work, haunted me all day. Rather than approaching the novel as Rabbit being a character I’m supposed to like, I came to feel that the novel is about the destruction and devastation that Rabbit causes in the lives around him. And then I realized that a book I had basically hated for the first 100 pages was turning into a book that really stuck with me, and hit me on a deep emotional level. This also must be on the best books for book club discussion I have ever read. I dog-eared no less than 20 pages with topics and ideas for conversation. It’s a book I want to discuss with people, to debate about, reflect upon. UPDATE: Randomly, the collection of short stories I am reading by David Foster Wallace includes a hilarious essay/criticism of John Updike, one of the premiere narcissistic men of the 1960s. In one sentence I think he encapsulated so much of Updike. He writes, in referring to the traditional Updike protagonist, "It never once occurs to him, though, that the reason he's so unhappy is that he's an asshole....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: These days with my commute, I read a book every week and a half or so. This book took my four weeks to read...as in, it literally took me four times aThese days with my commute, I read a book every week and a half or so. This book took my four weeks to read...as in, it literally took me four times as long as a book usually takes me. It is unquestionably the most dense, erudite book I have read since college. I wish I could say I loved it, but I just liked it. Rushdie is a master of prose, and it really does take a genius kind of mind to come up with a story like this. But I found it sort of scattered and disconnected, and hard to get emotionally invested in. By Book Three, I certainly found the book terribly tragic and sad, but I would have felt so much more if I cared about the main character, Saleem, who almost seems to make you not want to like him. That being said, I just read a  of the book by Stephen King, and he called it one of the best books he read this year, and an "epic social comedy in the vein of Dickens." Is it Dickensian? Certainly. But maybe I missed the joke, because I just found it sad and a little rambling. And I wanted more of the book to focus on the actual Midnight's Children, those 1,001 children born in India during India's first hour of independence. Their magical powers, from telepathy to walking through walls, would have been a great way to liven up the story.The best, and in my opinion, most accurate analysis/insight on the book I think comes from my friend Russell: "Westerners read "Midnight's Children" as magical realism; Indians read it as their history." I challenge you to read the book and tell me what you think....more

A wizard detective with a dark past is working to make amends (and money) by partnering with the Chicago PD to solve crimes where magic has been involved. Wizards live in the open and are both feared and revered for their many talents, and Harry Dresden has a fun, sardonic quality to him that makes you root for him. My one criticism of an otherwise entertaining read? The book ties up all the loose ends way too neatly in the last TWO pages. I always hate when I’m reading a book and you’re not at the climax yet and you’ve only got 10 pages left. title: Bonk: The Curious Coupling of Science and Sex
author: Roach, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Contrary to what you might think, this is not a sexy book. In fact, on more than one occasion, it's the sort of crossing your legs in fear and horror Contrary to what you might think, this is not a sexy book. In fact, on more than one occasion, it's the sort of crossing your legs in fear and horror kind of book that makes you never quite look at human sexual behavior the same way again. It’s a science book (or rather, a scientific book for lay people – no pun intended), and lord only knows what the people on BART or MUNI must have been thinking if they were reading it over my shoulder. That said, this is also a damn funny book, and Mary Roach is so laugh-out-loud funny that she makes the squeamish or horrifying parts more bearable. For those familiar with the Bay Area (Roach lives in Oakland), you will genuinely never look at your neighborhood again, as Roach does some of her research for the book locally. And while I can honestly say that I learned many things that I would have been happy never, ever knowing about, I also learned a lot of interesting things. For example, how is it that paraplegics who are paralyzed from the waist down can still have orgasms? I also learned a great deal about the inner workings of female anatomy, which I would be willing to bet most people don’t know…but they should, especially for the overall health of our society. I’m not sure what cocktail party I can use my newfound trivia at, but here’s hoping someone asks what smells make a female rhesus monkey randy, because now I know. ...more
