my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Time travel is a tricky thing to write, and Edwards does an admirable job with it. Sure, it ties up too neat and tidy at times, and sometimes it is juTime travel is a tricky thing to write, and Edwards does an admirable job with it. Sure, it ties up too neat and tidy at times, and sometimes it is just plain ridiculous or skirts out of dangerous literary territory far too quickly, but he deserves credit for making a time travel novel that doesn't completely lose the reader. The one thing I will say for the book is the eerie sort of overlap the book had with places I've lived (sans time travel, of course). And that was part of the reason I picked it up. A Jewish man living in San Francisco in 1988 is shot, and finds that on the brink of death he time travels back to 1897 Vienna...and that's all I'll share. Ok, I lied. He all too conveniently seeks out the most famous Viennese Jew of the time, Sigmund Freud, which is one of the weaker sections of the book, in my opinion. It felt gimmicky and trying to hard. But the protaganist is also faced with the moral dilemma of seeking out the child Hitler, and whether or not to change history irrevocably through the destruction of a child.The book takes place, in alternating points, in Vienna, San Francisco, Berkeley, Boston, and Yale, which sums up most of the places I've called home since I was 18. And the strong themes about being a Jew in Vienna at the rise of anti-semitism resonated very close to home, given my in-laws family history in Vienna. All in all entertaining, but not life changing. ...more

review: I picked this book up on a whim at the SF library last week because I finished the book I was reading on my way to work and needed something to read fI picked this book up on a whim at the SF library last week because I finished the book I was reading on my way to work and needed something to read for the ride home. To be honest, the synopsis on the book jacket didn't exactly grab me, but I was in a pinch and needed something to read, and I figured if anyone could make this interesting, it would be Ann Patchett.Here's the thing: Patchett is just so damn talented. She has a way of capturing the little nuances that make a person/character whole, that makes them come to life off a page and makes you instantly care about them. That's no small feat. In just 10 pages I cared about these people. Really cared, for seemingly inexplicable reasons. But that's why she is so remarkable...so subtle, so gifted, and capable of making paint dry completely riveting.My one thing with this book, and Bel Canto: the last chapter. I think Patchett doesn't know how to finish a story, or her editors pressure her to keep it under 350 pages, when she's the sort of writer who could skillfully use additional pages to tell her story. I loved the story until the last chapter, which, like Bel Canto, felt a little rushed and trying to tie up the ends too quickly. I don't need so many ends to be tied -- it diminishes the story's quality and feels unbelievable. Ann, you're awesome. Your audience is smarter than that. I promise....more

title: Home: A Memoir of My Early Years
author: Andrews Edwards, Julie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Maybe (like everything in life) it's all about expectations. I didn't have much for this book, and I was so pleasantly, wonderfully surprised by how eMaybe (like everything in life) it's all about expectations. I didn't have much for this book, and I was so pleasantly, wonderfully surprised by how entertaining it was. First, when Julie Andrews writes, you can hear her saying the words -- she has a wonderfully authentic voice. The book focuses on her life before super stardom (in fact, it ends as she is about to go onto the "Mary Poppins" set), and really is about her childhood (tougher than you'd expect) and growing up on the vaudeville circuit in wartime London, and then her move to America to originate the roles of Eliza Doolittle in "My Fair Lady" and Queen Guinevere in "Camelot." The people who are "characters" in her book are the Broadway icons of today -- Rodgers, Hammerstein, Sondheim, Bernstein, etc. And just like her, they were trying to make it, and weren't the legends we see them as now. If you're at all interested in the history of Broadway or vaudeville, it's a great summer read. It might be (dare I say it) "practically perfect in every way." ...more

review: Arguably Allende's most famous novel, and while I enjoyed it, truth be told I've liked some of her later works better. The book is based (how closely,Arguably Allende's most famous novel, and while I enjoyed it, truth be told I've liked some of her later works better. The book is based (how closely, I'm not sure) on the story of her own family, and goodness is it interesting and ultimately tragic. An interesting book to read right now, when there is so much fear mongering (in my opinion) being done by the Republican party, claiming the end of the world because a liberal is in power. You don't think something like this could happen today, but when you see Fox News, it gives you pause to think. But I digress.One literary device she used that drove me crazy was her foreshadowing into the future (as in, "She would not see him for another two years, at which point, he would be dead.") It builds suspense in a J.J. Abrams, "Lost" sort of way, but the problem is that I'd read it and think, "Dang it! This person dies?!" instead of "Oh wow, I wonder how he dies." Just more melodramatic than I really needed....more

title: The Best American Travel Writing 2007
author: Orlean, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This anthology overall was an immense disappointment, and I think much of the blame lies on the shoulders of the editor, Susan Orleans. This collectioThis anthology overall was an immense disappointment, and I think much of the blame lies on the shoulders of the editor, Susan Orleans. This collection was so hit and miss (mostly miss), that I questioned her judgment for being to tell a good story from a bad one. At the root of my disappointment is my struggle with the question, “What is a travel essay?” If you left your couch and wrote about it, does that qualify as a travel essay? Or what about a piece on the legislative process of making a tiny protectorate island a nation? Because it takes place in a country outside of the United States, despite having nothing to do with traveling, does that make it a travel essay?Many of the selections in the anthology belonged in Time or Newsweek -- they were not essays, but rather pieces for Time or Newsweek that were too long to print, so they ended up in this book. Other efforts felt phoned in – Ann Patchett, an author I greatly enjoy, wrote an entertaining but amazingly brief piece (three pages) that ended before it began. Jonathan Stern’s piece on “The Lonely Planet Guide to My Apartment” felt contrived and smug, and not nearly as entertaining as the name suggested.That being said, there were a handful of essays that were real gems – those included David Rakoff’s piece on Hollywood Blvd, Steve Friedman’s essay on a 410-pound man walking across America to find happiness, and the one of the best short stories I have read in years: “The Incredible Buddha Boy,” by George Saunders. It was the only story of the whole anthology that I couldn’t put down. A writer for GQ, I hope Saunders will consider publishing his own collection of short stories in the future. Saunders understood what (to me) makes a great travel story – insight, wit, respect for the culture/country that you are visiting, and a sense for making the reader feel that they are experiencing it with you. Fine, fine writing....more

review: There are books that center around unlikable characters that are still great books -- ones that you put down and are grateful that you spent time readThere are books that center around unlikable characters that are still great books -- ones that you put down and are grateful that you spent time reading. This is not one of those books. I found the characters shallow and unlikable, which was partly on purpose by the author -- she wants you to see her subtle irony and know that she's making fun of the self-obsessed 30-something in Manhattan who still live with their parents. But she also made a book that is not enjoyable to read, that feels trite and cliche. Essentially it was the anti-thesis of what I wanted to read over the holidays, and while it's won a slew of awards, I don't see why. Maybe because I'm not sucked into to the world of the uber-rich in NYC (which many award committees are connected to) I don't 'get' it, but given the current economic climate, I don't want to listen to the rantings and complaints of the young, rich, elite, who have scarcely worked a day in their life....more

review: A great read -- both literary and entertaining. "The Graveyard Book" is Gaiman's take on Kipling's, "The Jungle Book," and he does Kipling proud. WhilA great read -- both literary and entertaining. "The Graveyard Book" is Gaiman's take on Kipling's, "The Jungle Book," and he does Kipling proud. While Kipling's novel begins with the murder of Mowgli's family (and infant Mowgli's deposit by his mother into the jungle), Gaiman's protagonist -- later named "Bod," short for "Nobody" -- escapes a similar situation, when his family is brutally killed, and he toddles his way into the local graveyard. Bod then spends his childhood raised by ghosts, spirits, and the undead of the graveyard, and finding himself in adventures that would make Kipling proud. Gaiman also successfully translates the story to 21st century UK, and manages to make a novel that is both contemporary and timeless (as all fairy tales should be). ...more

title: New Moon        (The Twilight Saga, #2)
author: Meyer, Stephenie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You know how every once in a while a great little movie comes along, and it does surprising well, and the movie studio says "Great! We'll make a sequeYou know how every once in a while a great little movie comes along, and it does surprising well, and the movie studio says "Great! We'll make a sequel." And you find out about it, and think to yourself, "Really? A sequel? Why mess with a good thing?"That, in a nutshell, is how I felt about this book. I felt like the author thought that she needed to create some huge unexpected drama to keep the story going, and the problem is, the drama she creates completely contradicts everything she laid out in the first book. And if you bought into the original story line, you keep telling yourself how stupid this is, and how false the drama feels. The drama that takes up a whopping 400 PAGES of this book takes away from the true relationship at the core of "Twilight," the very thing that made people keep reading. You're then left with the flaws in the book that you sort of overlooked the first time because you liked the story so much. It reminded me a lot of "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix," where you felt like Rowling was bashing you over the head with the fact that Harry is an angry, frustrated teenager (We get it, Rowling). You find yourself becoming irritated with a character you want to be rooting for. And heavens, can someone please give Meyer (and Rowling, for that matter) a real editor? Someone who actually edits things out of a story? I don't need to know that Bella eats a lot of pizza, lasagne, and granola bars. I get it. Let's keep things moving, please.The good thing is that in the last 200 pages, Meyer seems to get her act together, and she lays the groundwork for some interesting storylines, which makes me eager to continue the series. And did anyone read the acknowledgments? Any author who gives a shout-out to the band Muse for inspiring some of her stories is pretty darn nifty to me. Onward to trek through more of the teen vampire chronicles......more

title: Twilight        (The Twilight Saga, #1)
author: Meyer, Stephenie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is it a Young Adult book? Yes. Is it the most amazing prose I’ve ever read? No. But is it the most page-turning book I’ve read in at least a year? Oh Is it a Young Adult book? Yes. Is it the most amazing prose I’ve ever read? No. But is it the most page-turning book I’ve read in at least a year? Oh gosh, yes. “Twilight” lured me in from the very first chapter, and I read all 500 pages of it in just four days (ok, ok, the font size is slightly bigger than an adult book). Meyer masterfully captures the electric moments of your first love, as well as the awkward social moments that come with the high school territory – with a little vampire action thrown in for extra measure. It’s an interesting premise to work with – girl falls for boy who is secretly a vampire, boy resists girl as long as he can because he loves her and finds her nearly irresistible, and is constantly dealing with the inner demons of wanting to eat her…which would put a damper on the relationship. Read into that what you will, but it’s an interesting way to look at the two sides of passion, and the thin razor’s edge that separates positive and negative passion. The book was also pretty suspenseful, and – dare I say? – sexy. Young adult books weren’t nearly as passionate and seductive when I was younger, but this is a more accurate depiction of passion and raging hormones than what you see in a lot of YA novels. On the whole, a completely engrossing and entertaining read, regardless your age....more

review: I really debated about what rating to give this book. While Mortenson's story was very uplifting, I ultimately found the whole message hampered by theI really debated about what rating to give this book. While Mortenson's story was very uplifting, I ultimately found the whole message hampered by the use of a ghost writer, whose writing style is too journalistic at times, and at other times verges on idolatry. The emotional moments of the book were rendered flat because of the lackluster storytelling of the writer, David Oliver Relin. In truth, when I bought the book, I didn't realize it had a ghost writer. It's such a shame. I realize that because Mortenson is so busy doing the wonderful work that he does, he doesn't have the time to write a book. And the sales of this book will allow CAI to be solidly funded for years to come. But I really struggled with the book, especially the middle section, and only continued reading it out of respect for the work that Mortenson does. To my knowledge, I'm the only member of the book club that did finish it -- the first 50 pages put a lot of people off, which is saying something, given that we are the target demographic for the book (educated do-gooders who believe in the value of education to fight terror). If Mortenson ever comes to town to speak, I'll certainly see him. But Relin's telling of his story really didn't do him any favors....more

title: When a Crocodile Eats the Sun: A Memoir of Africa
author: Godwin, Peter*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Godwin's "When a Crocodile Eats the Sun" is not only compelling and well-written, but more timely than ever. A memoir of his adult life after having lGodwin's "When a Crocodile Eats the Sun" is not only compelling and well-written, but more timely than ever. A memoir of his adult life after having left Zimbabwe, the place of his birth (he is a journalist for National Geographic and a slew of other top-notch publications), Godwin painfully portrays the experience of white Africans in Zimbabwe, and his own family's history in their journey to Africa. It gives an insider's view of Mugabe's reign of terror, and the utter chaos that has enveloped the country.Perhaps the most compelling part of the story is that of his parents, elderly in the late 90s and early 2000s. Anyone who has cared for an aging loved one, and who feels the guilt of the child or grandchild who is no longer at home to care for them, is struck by this emotional theme in the story. Add to this feeling the fact that his aging parents are in a conflict torn country with few resources, wild inflation, and rampant crime and intimidation, and you get a sense of the emotional and moral dilemma Godwin goes through. His parents are rooted in their home country and won't leave, but their children cannot viably stay; indeed, one of Godwin's siblings is a casualty of random violence during the Civil War. Godwin and his remaining sister act as international voices on the crisis, she on the radio, he in print. This is a heartbreaking and riveting book, which can be paired daily with the newspaper to show how so little has changed in Zimbabwe (the book ends in 2004), and how Mugabe's reign of terror last until this day. ...more

review: While I enjoyed the first "Persepolis" more, her second novel hit a more personal chord for me because the first 100 pages took place in Vienna, AustrWhile I enjoyed the first "Persepolis" more, her second novel hit a more personal chord for me because the first 100 pages took place in Vienna, Austria -- my home for half of 2007. While I am in no way saying our lives paralleled one another,I had many similar experiences being an, at times, less than welcome foreigner there. For those of you who read my blog, you'd see that she and I had many similar observations about the city -- the Viennese obsession with death, the trials and tribulations of the grocery store, and just simply being from a country that wasn't particularly popular in the world -- and how that frames your experience. Even the neighborhoods she lived in, and the fact that her friend's mother also worked at the UN -- it made the memoir hit a striking note with me. I was a little less satisfied with the ending -- perhaps because Satrapi is still young, and so you know she has so many experiences left to live, and as such it doesn't feel like an ending. But all in all the series was excellent and worth the quick read....more

title: Sex, Drugs, and Cocoa Puffs: A Low Culture Manifesto
author: Klosterman, Chuck
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Klosterman was recommended to me by a friend, and while I'll admit he has some funny bits, he really is that guy at the party who is exceedingly nerdyKlosterman was recommended to me by a friend, and while I'll admit he has some funny bits, he really is that guy at the party who is exceedingly nerdy (in a hipster sort of way) and who thinks he's clearly better than everyone else. And no one -- no one -- should devote the amount of time and attention to pop culture that he does. And this is coming from a girl who gets a regular dose of Perez Hilton every week. I'm his target audience, and yet he still turned me off. He critiques pop culture at such a level of extreme minutia that only four people on the planet know what he's talking about. Furthermore, he makes a point of saying that certain shows, bands, etc. appeal only to people who were born between certain years (he was born in 1972, and thinks most of today's pop culture only applies to those born between 1970 and 1975). For example, he writes that only people born between the aforementioned years ever watched "Saved By the Bell," which aired when he was in college. I won't get into the fact that Klosterman was watching episodes of SBTB in COLLEGE (mind you, this was a show on Saturday mornings initially, geared towards the 10-15 year-old crowd). In fact, I think SBTB was watched by many more viewers in younger generations than his, but it serves to illustrate the point that Klosterman seems to feel that everything in pop culture only applies to his narrow generational window.He writes as if he thinks he so much better than all of these people he makes fun of, and yet he spends his career hyper-evaluating pop culture. Pot, Kettle, anyone?...more

title: A Confederacy of Dunces
author: Toole, John Kennedy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this book on Todd's recommendation, and I'm a bit mixed on it. I think the story of the book and how it came to be is more famous than the actuI read this book on Todd's recommendation, and I'm a bit mixed on it. I think the story of the book and how it came to be is more famous than the actual story. John Kennedy Toole shopped the book around for years, and no one would publish it. He became so depressed he ultimately committed suicide (he was only in his 30s). His mother continued shopping the book around after he died, and finally a publisher agreed to release it. It then went on to win the Pulitzer Prize.The book is completely about character development rather than a moving storyline, and I will say that Ignatius Reilly is one of the most well-crafted and memorable characters I've ever read. He's also not the most likeable, but he's not supposed to be. I almost gave up on the book about 150 pages in because I was so turned off by the character, but I'm glad I stuck with it because he does grow on you a little, and Toole does a great job of weaving all the related storylines together in ingenious ways. Also an interesting look at New Orleans in the '60s....more

review: I first read “Beloved” when I was 16, and to read it now, nearly twice as old, I found it even more devastating. It’s the sort of book that every AmerI first read “Beloved” when I was 16, and to read it now, nearly twice as old, I found it even more devastating. It’s the sort of book that every American should be required to read, but it’s a book you’ll probably not want to read again. The prose is gorgeous – there’s no question that Morrison is an outstanding writer – but I almost got desensitized to the horrors over time. The story wears you down, which I feel terrible even saying because all I had to do was read about the horrors, not actually live them. I was surprised by how much of the book I had forgotten…all the more surprising because there will be moments from that book that I will never get out of my head. A bit like Saramago’s “Blindness.” I’ve read four books by Morrison, and while “Beloved” is easily her most famous, I still think “Song of Solomon” is her best....more

title: The Secret Garden
author: Hodgson Burnett, Frances
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This has always been one of my favorite childhood stories. Reading it as an adult, I almost loved it more. It made me realize how much this book shapeThis has always been one of my favorite childhood stories. Reading it as an adult, I almost loved it more. It made me realize how much this book shaped a part of who I am. Growing up, I lived in a house that was on a canyon at the end of the cul-de-sac. You could walk along the canyon’s edge just beyond our house, and there was a small, U-shaped inlet that was full of wild native plants. Pretty much from the first day we moved into that house this little inlet (completely hidden by the hedge on our property line) became my ‘secret garden.’ One of the nicest things my Dad did for me as a child was that he cut a hole in his hedge so that I would have my own private entry into the garden (grown-ups could just use the walking path). I had smaller versions of gardening tools, and I cultivated my own little garden of wildflowers. I kept thinking about this as I reread the book, and thought of the other message that I didn’t necessarily pick up as a child: the message that being active and out of doors is necessary for a child to be healthy and thrive. Basic and obvious, yes, but that message stuck with me more as an adult, as so many of our friends start families and we start thinking about having our own one day. I started thinking about how kids today don’t spend as much time outdoors (I don’t blame them, per se, there are a lot of reasons). And I hoped they would find the magic in the book (and the surprising complex character development) that I found I loved even more as an adult. On the day I finished the book, I had just come in from spending three hours in the backyard of our (new to us) fixer-upper home. I had been pruning our beautiful, mature orange tree that was overhanging onto the neighbor’s yard (and pushing on the back fence to the point that I thought it might break it), as well as pruning our lemon tree, both of which had been neglected for years. It was difficult work – sawing the limbs off with one hand, holding the limb in the other hand so that it didn’t drop in the neighbor’s yard when sawed, only then to have to pull the heavy, fruit-laden branches back over the fence onto our side of the yard. But it felt so good do it, even though I was getting scratched by branches and covered in dust and dirt and insects. I stood on our back porch when it was all done and could see how much better our yard looks. It was so nice to see the results of hard work tangible in front of you. And I thought of the book and hoped that I could instill this same love into our kids some day. ...more

title: March
author: Brooks, Geraldine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: March was, at times, unexpectedly moving, and often I couldn't put it down. As a work of historical fiction it's top-notch, seemlessly blending the unMarch was, at times, unexpectedly moving, and often I couldn't put it down. As a work of historical fiction it's top-notch, seemlessly blending the unknown life of a fictional character (Mr. March of Alcott's "Little Women") during the Civil War, and the true life stories of individuals of the time. I've never been a Civil War buff ("Gone with the Wind" has informed much of my Civil War history knowledge sadly), but reading this book has made me contemplate picking up other books of the time period, and Brooks makes some great recommendations in the afterword.Above all this though, I thought Brooke's greatest accomplishment in the book was in portraying the love and relationship between Mr. March and Marmee March -- complex, passionate, and all too imperfect and real. By showing what happens when we try to be what we think the other person wants us to be, and the results of a lack of true communication (all because you love a person too much to want to disappoint them), as well as the gray area between long held ideals and philosophies and the reality you actually encounter, Brooks does a fantastic job of creating a haunting, true-to-life relationship between two people whom you know so little about from Alcott's novel. Really, really enjoyable....more

title: The Bone People
author: Hulme, Keri
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While I was reading "The Bone People," two of my colleagues saw I had it and asked what I thought so far -- apparently both of them couldn't finish itWhile I was reading "The Bone People," two of my colleagues saw I had it and asked what I thought so far -- apparently both of them couldn't finish it. I can see why. It's a challenging book, slow in parts, and the subject matter (child abuse, overtones of sexual abuse from a community member) can make it hard to read. Just at the turning point in the novel (around page 300) I almost put the book down, but figured that I've already put the time in to read 300 pages, what's 150 more? I'm glad I did. The story takes an unexpected shift, and while I didn't love it, it made me appreciate it much more.I give Hulme credit because she manages to make Joe, a character who on paper should be hated and despised, someone you can empathize with on some level. Hulme has crafted very real (albeit screwed up) characters whom you feel for, even if you completely disagree with their behavior. A telling sign for me of the emotional impact of the book was when one of the same colleagues said to me, "You know, I still think about that book. I want to know what happens to the characters." I did too, and in my eyes that's the sign of a good storyteller. ...more

Maybe I'm just not well-versed in graphic novels, but I found it hard to follow at times, and if I hadn't seen the movie I would have been very lost indeed. It's a great concept, and an interesting commentary on British society (written during the Thatcher era about the unspecified future), but I just expected it to be so much better. review: Stranger in a Strange Land (the uncut edition) is one my brother's all-time favorite sci-fi books, and he's been telling me to read it for some time. Stranger in a Strange Land (the uncut edition) is one my brother's all-time favorite sci-fi books, and he's been telling me to read it for some time. I enjoyed the book, though it wasn't at all what I expected it to be. I can appreciate it for being well ahead of its time in so many regards, and provocative even, but at the end of the day I had a hard time sitting down and reading it for long periods of time. Perhaps because there was a lot to digest, I'd have to come back to it. But as a result it took me a long time to get through it. Not necessarily a bad thing (sometimes the best books take time), but I wouldn't pack it in your bag for a vacation weekend. Oh, and there was some irony for me because I read it while I'm living in Austria, and feeling a bit like a stranger myself....more

title: The Soft Vengeance of a Freedom Fighter, New Edition
author: Sachs, Albie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those amazing books that NO ONE has read, and it's an absolute shame. Sachs is a friend of the anthropology chair at UC Berkeley, and iThis is one of those amazing books that NO ONE has read, and it's an absolute shame. Sachs is a friend of the anthropology chair at UC Berkeley, and in taking her class freshman year we all were required to read it. Albie Sachs is a lawyer on the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in South Africa, a court that deals with the acts if apartheid in a unique way. Anyone can come before the TRC and essentially 'confess' their acts, and in return they will not be charged. It's been surprisingly effective in healing the wounds of apartheid in the country.Sachs worked closely with the ANC and Mandela, and in 1988 was the victim of a car bomb in Mozambique. He wakes up to find he has lost his arm and vision in one of his eyes. What follows is an incredibly moving story of his physical recovery from injuries, while around him apartheid is being dismantled and the country must begin to emotionally heal from its injuries.Sachs came to speak at Berkeley a year later, and he's a remarkable man, a true hero who's story will likely go unnoticed by most. SUCH a good book. ...more

title: The Lost: A Search for Six of Six Million
author: Mendelsohn, Daniel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A friend of mine gave me her copy of this book, telling me I should read it because of the intimacy my own life has had in recent years to the HolocauA friend of mine gave me her copy of this book, telling me I should read it because of the intimacy my own life has had in recent years to the Holocaust. My boyfriend's grandparents were both Holocaust survivors who emigrated to the US after the war. The book focuses on one man's search to find out more about 'the lost,' six members of his family (an aunt, uncle, and four cousins) who perished in the war, but no one knows exactly how. He travels to multiple countries over several years interviewing Jews from his family's tiny town in what is now Ukraine. The similarities between this man's family and what I know of the experiences of my boyfriend's family were in many cases eerily and s unsettlingly similar. You have to work at reading this book -- it's nearly 600 pages -- and the subject matter and prose can sometimes make you feel like you're hardly making any headway. It's not a quick read, but by the end you feel an intimacy with the author. You wish you could just call him up and talk to him about his experiences. I think anyone who is interested in the Holocaust, or can appreciate the journey of trying to discover more about your family and your heritage, will enjoy reading this book....more
